QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: FEDERATED SHIP PAINTERS AND DOCKERS UNION

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Prime Minister. Firstly, has the Government had interim report No. 3 of Mr Costigan, the Royal Commissioner inquiring into the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, since 18 December 1981? Secondly, does that report contain specific recommendations asking the Government to take action to amend section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and to amend the Royal Commission's terms of reference? Thirdly, is the Prime Minister aware that the Commissioner says in his report that such amendment 'is directed to the enhancement of the investigative capabilities of the Commission' and 'would require early legislation if it is to be of use to the Commission'? Finally, in the light of the foregoing and of the Prime Minister's allegations in this House on 18 February about another person, will he tell the House why, having had this report for nearly three months, he has refused to take action to see that these recommendations of the Royal Commissioner are implemented?

—I understand from my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services that the report was received on or about the date mentioned by the honourable member for Wills. The answer to the second part of the question is yes, and I think the answer to a large part of the third part of the question is also yes, in that the honourable member was quoting the words of the Royal Commissioner himself. It was indicated in my colleague's tabling statement of a week or so ago that the Government would give early attention to the recommendation of the Royal Commissioner. I add only that I wish to emphasise something that appears to have been lost sight of in all of what has been said arising out of the Royal Commissioner's interim report, namely, that the particular tax evasion practice that was described in such colourful terms by the Royal Commissioner was in fact declared a criminal offence by an Act of this Parliament, at the initiative of this Government, about 16 months ago.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Communications, refers to reports of an offer of a gift of $200,000 to the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I ask: Was a bequest from the estate of a Mr Ian Douglas Reed offered to the Commission on 2 March 1979? Have the solicitors for the estate been offering the money to the ABC since then? If so, what is preventing the ABC from accepting it?

—Like the honourable gentleman, I was most concerned when I learned of the gift from an article in a newspaper. Apparently the difficulty in the Australian Broadcasting Commission's accepting it is that it was made to a specific division of the Commission and the constitution governing the Commission and its ability to receive a gift drafted in that form have been under consideration by the Attorney-General and by other lawyers. I have asked the Chairman of the ABC to ensure that nothing within the Commission will hinder an early consideration of the gift. I believe that, given the purposes of the bequest which I understand is directed to activities of a general educational character, it is well suited to the general operations of the Commission and I hope that it will be able to take up the offer. I certainly hope that, as a result of my discussions with the Commission, it will be possible for the gift to proceed and for the existing apparent legal impediments to be resolved.

—I ask the Minister for Health whether it is a fact that the Minister's $30m costing of Labor's plan to extend free pharmaceuticals to unemployed beneficiaries and their dependants, who totalled 457,725 persons in November 1981, would mean the provision of an average of 20 prescriptions a year for each of these unemployed beneficiaries and their dependants. Also, as the average number of Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme prescriptions for all Australians is only eight a year, can the Minister explain why his, or his Department's costing is apparently based on the assumption that unemployed beneficiaries are pharmaceutical drug addicts?
—I am very grateful to the honourable member for allowing me to draw attention to yet another of the miscostings in the Australian Labor Party' s health plan. The fact of the matter is that-
—You did not convince me on Sunday.
—The honourable member has an absence of thought processes so I can understand why it would not convince him.
—There are a lot like me.

—They generally vote for the ALP. The Government estimates the cost of the additional expenditure in the pharmaceutical area as $30m, not $10m , as estimated for unemployed beneficiaries by the honourable member for Bonython. The Government's figure does not allow for the number of prescriptions a year suggested by the honourable member. It allows for an average of 15 prescriptions a year for each patient, compared with 22 for people who are currently receiving free pharmaceuticals-
—Come off it, that is for the aged and infirm. This is a fraud.
—The sick and the dying, you idiot.

—I ask the Minister to resume his seat. I indicate to the Leader of the Opposition that he should not interject in the fashion he has. I also indicate to the honourable member for Bonython that because he disagrees with what the Minister is saying it does not entitle him to use offensive words. The honourable member for Bonython will remain silent. The Leader of the Opposition will remain silent. I call the Minister for Health.
—The honourable members of the Opposition are very touchy about this subject because, in fact, they have not costed their scheme correctly.
—It is so absurd.

—The honourable gentleman who professes to be an academic should allow me to continue with my answer and listen with an open mind rather than interrupt and try to prevent me from giving a full answer. The estimate was based on the fact that it has been clearly demonstrated that doctors are more likely to prescribe for a greater patient use of prescriptions when those pharmaceutical products are free. Secondly, scripts would also be available free for items costing less than $3.20 which are not covered now because that is the minimum patient contribution. So there would be more items covered. Finally, the pensioner health benefit scheme also includes additional items not generally available under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. That answers the question as to why it is more likely that people would obtain more prescriptions when those prescriptions are free. Firstly, patients would expect them; secondly, doctors would be encouraged to give them; thirdly,-
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that it was I who asked the question.
—I call the Minister for Health.

—Mr Speaker, as required by Standing Orders, I will address my answer through the Chair to the honourable lady. Finally, the ALP's costings take no account of the promise contained in the so-called Hayden health plan for reduced pharmaceutical costs for people with chronic illnesses. It does not detail what those chronic illnesses are and what the reduction of the fee would be. The fact of the matter is that it is very difficult to calculate the costs of chronic illness patients-of course, they would be high users of pharmaceutical items-and I would be very grateful to the Labor Party if it would make clear which chronic illnesses it is going to make fee reductions for and what the extent of these fee reductions will be. On the figures available to me, the estimates provided by the Government are based on experience overseas and a conservative estimate of the cost of supplying pharmaceuticals at reduced cost to people with chronic illnesses.

—My question to the Treasurer concerns the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and its conclusion that bank mortgage interest rates should be deregulated. Is the Treasurer aware that the Committee concluded that, with deregulation, bank mortgage rates would rise from their current level of 12 1/2 per cent to the Government bond rate, now at 15 per cent? Is the Treasurer also aware that a recent study by two economists at the Australian National University Centre for Economics Policy Research showed that at the interest rate levels prevailing last December deregulation would raise the average mortgage interest rate from 13.6 per cent to between 17 per cent and 18 per cent? In view of these horrendous interest rate consequences that would flow from deregulation and the great concern in the community about the future course of interest rates, will the Treasurer now assure the House that the Government will reject out of hand the Campbell Committee proposal for deregulation of interest rates?

—I am aware of the conclusions reached in the Campbell Committee report . In fairness to the report I think I should point out to the honourable gentleman that the conclusion was that certain interest rates would suffer the rises suggested by the honourable gentleman, other interest rates could well fall and that it could well be that the average cost of money borrowed might not vary over time a great deal at all. I think in all the debate on this issue variations in the average cost of money over a period have to be borne in mind. I have made it clear on a number of occasions that the recommendations of the Campbell report are relevant to what the Government is looking at in the housing area. I do not intend to respond to the invitation of the honourable member for Gellibrand and in any way pre-empt a decision of the Cabinet at this time or at some future time on that or other recommendations of the Campbell report.

—Does the Treasurer have information on the extent of finance available to intending house purchasers? Are funds invested with permanent building societies around Australia being maintained at satisfactory levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without obtaining a good deal of statistical information-which I will get for the honourable gentleman-it is not easy to give a totally precise answer to that question. A number of patterns are apparent. It is fair to say that over the past couple of years-particularly over the last 12 months-savings banks in particular have fared badly in deposit gathering. The rise in deposits for savings banks over the last 12 months has probably been around 7 per cent, which represents a significant fall in real terms. It is also true that permanent building societies, which for a number of years did very well in relation to savings banks, over the past 12 months have experienced a tapering off in their deposit gathering capacity. They have probably suffered a little more through the competition of other deposit taking institutions which offer higher rates of interest.

ANSWER.PARA: I did indicate last week, and I repeat it to the House, that in reaching decisions and conclusions on the housing issue one has to keep a sense of proportion. Whilst it is true that by the standards of, say, 1974 and 1975 the overall volume of money available for housing is still very high, it is equally true that over the past 12 months a downward trend has developed. For the benefit of the honourable gentleman and the House I will bring together some statistical information which, in any event, is already available publicly. Perhaps it can be more conveniently put together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Health to page 85 of Budget Paper No. 1 where the estimate of revenue forgone as a result of the new health insurance rebate, in its first and partial year, is estimated to be of the order of $600m . I also refer him to his statement of 1 March 1982 in which the estimate of revenue forgone in a full year as a result of the health insurance rebate was put at $470m. If the Budget estimate is wrong, can the Minister firstly explain to the House why anyone should have confidence in his costings of other people' s schemes when he is so inept at costing his own? Secondly, given the huge discrepancy of his own figures and the need for rational debate on this issue, can he tell the House the point of time and the estimated fund membership on which his or the Taxation Office's latest calculation is based?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the honourable gentleman's sensitivity on the question of costing because it has been demonstrated quite clearly that his health plan has been inadequately costed. I would be grateful if he would elucidate or inform me how he arrived at his estimate of $660m.
—From the Budget Paper.
—From the Government's Budget Paper? Are you sure about that?
—And checked against other calculations.
—Which other calculations?
—Order! The Minister will address his reply through the Chair.
—I beg your pardon, Mr Speaker. I would be very interested to know the basis of the $660m calculated by the honourable gentleman.
—You are the one spreading the lies. Come on and explain them.
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat. The honourable member for Adelaide will withdraw.
—Mr Speaker, reluctantly I will withdraw.
—The honourable gentleman will withdraw unqualifiedly.
—I withdraw.
—I call the Minister for Health.
—The figure of $470m was calculated by taking the only complete set of membership figures for health insurance funds which were available to the Government and they were as at 30 September last year.

ANSWER.PARA: The point that I wish to make is that these figures were complete. They were the only ones available. The figures as at 30 November or later were only preliminary figures. As soon as the more complete figures become available to us-I hope that that will be within the next couple of weeks-an update will be given. But the fact of the matter remains that the figure of $470m was calculated using complete data and, therefore, it is the figure to be taken. The earlier figures mentioned in the Budget Papers were derived from estimates based on expected membership levels and expected levels within the health insurance parameters, that is, between hospital insurance, health insurance or combined insurance. The $470m was based on complete data available to the Government at the time. I mention that it was 30 September and not 1 September as the honourable member for Bonython put out in his rather emotional response to the Government's costings.

The fact of the matter is that the honourable gentleman holds himself out to be something of an academic. He does not check his figures. He does not even check his Press releases. I believe he would be subject to some castigation by any of his academic advisers because he does not even check the spelling of the words that he uses in his Press releases. If he cannot even spell correctly or he cannot even check his Press releases correctly, how can he possibly expect his figuring to be taken as accurate?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. Could the Minister now answer the question?
—There is no point of order.
—I ask the Minister for Science and Technology: Is it true that the Government plans to reduce the scale of Australian activities in Antarctica?

—There has been a good deal of misleading publicity on this question in the last few days. I am pleased with the publicity because perhaps it has done something to increase the awareness of honourable members and Australians generally of the importance of Antarctica to Australia. I assure the honourable member for Mackellar that there is no intention of closing any of Australia's four Antarctic and sub-Antarctic bases. They will be continued and maintained. The Government is committed to a $58m rebuilding plan for all the bases over the next ten years which gives some idea of the Government's commitment to Antarctica. There have been reports also that staff in the Antarctic Division has been reduced in recent times. That is not true. There has been no reduction of staff in the Antarctic Division over the last three years. When the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions recommended a 2 per cent across the board cut for all departments the Antarctic Division was excluded from the cut by my Department and its share of the cut was taken by the rest of the divisions. I believe that gives another indication of the Government's commitment to this very important area. Antarctica is important to Australia in a number of ways- scientifically, environmentally, for strategic reasons and, perhaps in the future, for resources.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for Health, follows the question directed to him by the honourable member for Bonython and refers, of course, to his answer. Mr Speaker, you will recall that the Minister, in his answer, confessed that he used a different basis for calculating the income forgone through the health insurance rebate introduced by the Government as against the estimate of revenue forgone he attributed to our health insurance scheme in this area. That, of course, is a very clever tactic, most honourable members will acknowledge.
—I ask the honourable gentleman to ask his question.

—To put the comparison on a fairer plane, will he state quite simply what percentage of the population was imputed as having membership of private health insurance funds for the purpose of the Government's arriving at the calculated result that the health insurance rebate revenue forgone cost $600m?

—I am sorry, I cannot give the honourable gentleman a precise answer to that question. But I can repeat that the estimates I have used in costing the modestly named 'Hayden health scheme' at $470m were based on actual figures available at 30 September 1981. The point remains, whatever the gyrations of the honourable gentlemen opposite, that they have underestimated very seriously the cost of the implementation of their plan-so much so that if they were honest about making up the shortfall the 0.75 per cent levy would be about 1.2 per cent.
—I take a point of order. Whilst some licence is allowed to Ministers, Ministers are not entitled to impute to members of the Opposition that they are not honest.
—I ask the Minister not to use a term which may be so interpreted. I did not interpret it in that fashion but the honourable member for Corio did. I ask the Minister not to repeat it.

—Let me say then that if they factually covered the additional cost required to implement the Labor Party health scheme that would involve a levy of approximately 1.2 per cent rather than 0.75 per cent as currently put forward. I would like to make one other point as well. We are talking about costs-figures are being thrown across the table. There is another aspect, and in my view a more important aspect, of this whole debate. What we are talking about is the level of health care which will be available to all Australians in the future.
—Order! The Minister is now not relevant to the question asked.

—Mr Speaker, can I just succinctly make the point that it is not only the cost of a health scheme which is important; the quality of health care which results from the implementation of any scheme is equally, if not more, important.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AIR SERVICES: MARANOA AND KENNEDY ELECTORATES

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Transport. What arrangements has the Minister's Department come to with the Queensland Government to enable essential air services to continue to operate in the Maranoa and Kennedy electorates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Government and the Queensland Government have agreed to provide a subsidy of up to $1m per annum from each government to maintain Trans Australia Airlines F27 services, even if on a reduced scale, to western and northern Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: As the honourable gentleman would know, with the introduction of the Holcroft formula for the setting of air fares it has not been possible for TAA to cross- subsidise fares in western Queensland with fares on other routes. The result has been, of course, that TAA has had to continue those services to western and inland northern Queensland at a loss of about $3m per annum.

The Commonwealth Government, in association with TAA and the Queensland Government, undertook a very thorough evaluation of the services that were being provided by TAA to Queensland. As a result of that examination it was decided to rationalise the services and so reduce the total loss to TAA to approximately $ 2m per annum.

There will be some reduction in frequencies in certain parts of the Maranoa electorate. There also will be some reductions in frequencies to the electorate of Kennedy. As the honourable member for Kennedy would understand, those reductions will be largely offset by an improved jet service between Townsville and Mount Isa.

I am sure that the people of Queensland will welcome the fact that this arrangement will apply at least until the 1983-84 financial year. Indeed, at the end of 1982-83 there will be a review of the level of subsidy. I expect that in that interim period attempts will be made by the Queensland Government and also by other airlines and other operators to look at providing a more effective service to the western and inland northern Queensland people without the need for a subsidy. It is hoped that by 1983-84 aircraft will have a capacity to operate more efficiently over such routes. We would be encouraging other airlines to take over as TAA may phase out of F27 aircraft within the next two years.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Prime Minister of his statement to the Australian and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Conference on 22 January 1975 in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: When political leaders say the present situation cannot be helped, it is part of a world situation, they are expressing the futility of their own leadership when if they were men of real stature, they would be saying 'we can overcome'.
I ask the Prime Minister this simple question: Does he still stand by that statement?

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought that from the policies we have pursued over a considerable number of years which have led the Australian economy to grow while the economies of other countries are shrinking and which have led to a situation in which the Australian economy is envied amongst advanced industrial countries, it is very plain that we are doing everything we can to adjust and modify our policies so that this country will be in a secure position and best able to withstand whatever difficulties come from overseas. We will continue to act in that way.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industry. Is consideration being given to implementing a single meat inspection system in this country? Can the Minister inform the House what progress has been made in this direction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the House knows there has been considerable debate on this question. I think there is general acceptance throughout the community of the need for a single meat inspection system. But as the House also knows the Commonwealth responsibility lies in respect of meat for the export trade. The State governments' responsibility lies, of course, with the domestic health services. It has been difficult for me as Commonwealth Minister to get State agreement to a single service. The nearest to a breakthrough has come with Victoria where the Minister of Agriculture has been pleased to join in a study to see whether we can get a single meat inspection service for Victoria. I am pleased to be able to report to the House that those studies are proceeding very satisfactorily. There are a number of difficulties yet to overcome but I think that progress will lead to a single service in that State. That will then set the pattern, I hope, for other States' consideration of the issue.

ANSWER.PARA: Western Australia has exhibited some interest in the study going on, as has Queensland. Regrettably, the honourable member's own State of New South Wales has displayed no interest at all in a single meat inspection service and I am not too sure how we will ever get it up to the barrier. The fact of the matter is that we now have a single meat inspection service operating in Tasmania, South Australia and the Northern Territory. If we can get Victoria up to the barrier I think we are well down the road to getting a number of the other States.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for Health, and again I refer to earlier questions about the costing of Labor's health insurance program. Is it a fact that the membership of private health insurance funds covered about 54 per cent of the population at September last year and that on that basis the income forgone from the health insurance rebate would be the equivalent of some $470m, the figure he has quoted? Is it a fact that his Department, however, in the post-November period worked and currently works on an assumption of 70 per cent membership of the Australian population in private health insurance funds and on that basis the figure quoted by the honourable member for Bonython of $ 660m is a correct and reliable figure? In the circumstances why has he traduced his Department by drawing it into this fraudulent costing exercise that he has engaged in?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of the honourable member's question, if I recall it correctly, suggested that the figure for people covered by health insurance was 53 per cent as at 1 September. To the best of my knowledge, that is incorrect. The figure was about 53 per cent at the end of March-April. The figure at 1 September would have been higher than that. The percentage figures at the end of September, upon which the estimates were based, were in the sixties. They were the first complete figures and are the only complete figures from all the health insurance funds which are yet available to the Government. I have already stated that the figures for later in the year are preliminary. We expect that we will receive the consolidated figures fairly soon. I would be very happy to provide the honourable member with an estimate once those consolidated figures for later in the year are available to us.

ANSWER.PARA: I make the point again that the honourable gentleman opposite knows that his estimates are false. They have been proved to be false. He has tried over a series of interviews to hoodwink the Australian people. It is a simple plan. So are confidence tricks simple plans. He knows it; the Australian people will know it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications. Is there any truth in allegations that Australia Post is to close or downgrade many country post offices? Will the Minister ensure that there are no reductions in the quality of postal services to rural areas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very happy to assure the honourable gentleman that the answer to the first part of his question is a very resounding no. The answer to the second part is yes and, of course, I hope the services will be improved. A campaign has been conducted, particularly in Victoria, around country postmasters. It has been designed to generate fear and concern amongst employees of Australia Post and recipients of the services of Australia Post. The whole system of Australia Post involves a continual appraisal of the needs of communities. As a result new post offices are opened from time to time. The honourable member for Petrie, Senator Georges and I participated in an opening of a new post office last week in one of the outer suburbs of Brisbane. From time to time changes are made too in the staffing requirements of different post offices. Australia Post, in the proper conduct of its business, reviews the needs of the community and endeavours to ensure that the staffing and the status of the post office meet those needs.

ANSWER.PARA: There is no program afoot in any way to downgrade or change the status of post offices as a result of any new program, review of Commonwealth functions report, or anything else. The whole of the operations of the post office are obviously designed to try to maintain the service that was so frustrated through the industrial troubles that were generated through the whole of the Redfern Mail Exchange period. The Redfern Mail Exchange was not a good working environment. Australia Post recognised that and has moved away from that centralised mail sorting establishment to establish decentralised mail sorting areas. These are working very efficiently. When that program is completed I have every reason to believe that throughout Australia the general services available will be at least as competitive as any that are available from any other postal system anywhere in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Science and Technology, is supplementary to that asked by the honourable member for Mackellar. Apart from the $58m rebuilding program in the Antarctic, how much money will be allocated for research? What steps have been taken to provide suitable equipment for the bases, including the purchase of supply ships? Bearing in mind that the Japanese and the Russians are fishing krill at the rate of 200,000 tonnes a year, what proposals does the Minister have in mind to harvest the enormous resources of the Antarctic?

—I welcome the question. I am delighted that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is showing such an interest in Antarctica. I cannot give him the details of the amount spent on scientific research in Antarctica. I will find them and let him know. I am aware that other nations have a great interest in the resources of Antarctica, particularly those in the surrounding sea. Australia is taking part in a number of scientific programs to discover as much as it can about these great resources. The scientific programs need to be upgraded. I hope that greater resources will be made available. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition is perhaps aware that the very large rebuilding program has put a drain on the resources of the Antarctic Division. The fact that we have to accommodate in the Antarctic bases a large number of building staff from the Department of Housing and Construction has drained the resources. This is a matter of concern to me and will be considered in the Budget context. I am well aware of the importance of scientific research in Antarctica and of increasing our efforts there. There has to be a balanced program. There is a great demand on the costs of the administration because of logistics and the rebuilding program. There is no doubt that we could spend very large sums of money in Antarctica. That has to be balanced with all the other demands on the Government , but I hope that we will be able to use increasing resources after the next Budget.

—My question is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade and Resources. What measures have been adopted by the Government to encourage the processing of raw materials to the secondary and tertiary stages? Is the Minister aware of the tremendous employment opportunities that would result from increased processing of such materials? What is the likelihood of there being a substantial increase in the processing of raw materials over the next few years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is firm Government policy to try to encourage the upgrading of raw materials in this country because of the new industries and greater job opportunities that can be created. As part of the process of trying to develop greater processing and upgrading of our raw materials, the Commonwealth and the States have been working together to survey the likely areas in which more could be done and to encourage more industries to invest in this circumstance. I believe that, with the potential we have for resource development in this country, processing and upgrading of raw materials will become a greater feature of our exports.
—I ask the Minister for Health a question.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The second Monday in March is set aside to mark Commonwealth Day and, as today is the closest sitting day, I would like to take this opportunity to emphasise the significance of the Commonwealth, and its importance for Australia. The Commonwealth has shown a remarkable capacity to adapt to changing world circumstances, especially in recent decades. It has a demonstrated capacity to maintain its own continuity through a process of evolution and subtle modification and at the same time it has a proven track record in solving problems. As Commonwealth Secretary-General Ramphal said in Melbourne last year, 'it is acknowledged that the Commonwealth can handle disagreement and generate accord'. He went on to say that 'our dialogue is one between friends within the community of the Commonwealth'. These views have been echoed by dozens of Commonwealth leaders.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Speaker, we live in a fragile and dangerous world in which there are few enough fruitful avenues open to the nations of the world to come to grips with the problems which confront us. Because this is so, we should all try to nourish and encourage any avenue which exists and which can do good, and the Commonwealth is, without doubt, an avenue which has a number of unique advantages. It brings together rich and poor, North and South. It cuts across many prevailing expectations of alignments among nations. It enables people with very different political philosophies to sit down together and work towards agreement on matters that would otherwise divide them.

The Commonwealth is the only forum in which heads of government set aside several days of their time every two years-in the case of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting leaders, every year-to address a range of problems of common concern. The informality and flexibility of the Commonwealth enable it to bring new and practical perspectives to bear on problems where the rest of the world community has sometimes found itself locked into sterile exchanges between structured groups. Commonwealth leaders have shown their determination to make the Commonwealth work. Difficulties and shortcomings have never been allowed to stand in the way, and there is no doubt that the Commonwealth warrants our continuing support.

This year, 1982, will be an important year for the Commonwealth. The third Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting will take place in Suva in October. This will be the first meeting of Commonwealth leaders in the Pacific Islands, and this has a particular significance following the emphasis given to issues of Pacific concern at last year's Commonwealth meeting. This meeting will involve Commonwealth Heads of Government from the Asian and Pacific Regions. The development of regional Commonwealth meetings was, as honourable members will know, an Australian initiative. We look to the meeting in Suva to carry forward the valuable and practical achievements of the two previous regional meetings in Sydney and New Delhi, and we would anticipate that a number of the issues considered in Melbourne last year will receive further attention at the Suva meeting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Today I would like the House to step back from the cut and thrust of everyday political life to consider the direction in which we wish to move as a nation over the next few years. This Parliament has a profound responsibility to keep abreast of the whole range of issues facing Australia. We need to understand Australia's position in a broad perspective as well as in detail, in the light of international as well as domestic factors. We need to understand the choices which lie ahead and the consequences of the decisions we take. We need a clear sense of our nation's values and objectives and we need to develop and explain our policies in the light of our philosophy. The world is full of uncertainty and, because of this, Australia needs a policy approach which is marked by balance, vision and realism . The world is also full of unrealistic demands and expectations in spite of the immediate social and economic problems which many countries are experiencing and which are having an indirect impact on most countries. In a situation of significant uncertainty and difficulty, it would obviously be absurd to expect that high and immediate expectations can be attained at little cost or as a matter of course. But neither should we allow the difficulties being experienced by the world economy to be seen in a way which gets them out of proportion-it would be wrong to overestimate or underestimate them. We need to try to understand them realistically because it is vital if we are to move ahead as one nation in the next few years that people's expectations should be closely adjusted to reality. Nobody has a crystal ball to predict the future fully but we do know that, unless we anticipate and adapt our policies in line with changing circumstances, unless we are in a position to take advantage of changes in the world economy as and when they occur, opportunities will pass Australia by.

SPEECH.PARA: We also know that the old adage that you only get out as much as you put in remains as true today as it has always been and it is timely to remember, when we are considering realistic levels of expectations, that what some people get cannot go to others.
The International Perspective

In coming to grips with Australia's present position in an overall perspective, it is appropriate to start with the international dimension. Our independence as a nation cannot blind us to the fact that overseas events affect us profoundly. Much of Australia's history bears witness to the recognition by earlier generations of Australians that we are affected by what happens in other parts of the world. At the present time, Australia cannot ignore the tensions and the threats which exist in so many parts of the world to international security and stability. The Soviet Union pursues its militaristic and opportunistic programs relentlessly. We see the effects of that policy in Afghanistan and Poland and in attempts to frustrate the peace process in the Middle East. We see it through Cuba's support for Communist insurrection in Africa and Latin America and, closer to home, Vietnamese troops continue to occupy Kampuchea, in violation of that country's sovereignty, and posing a threat to Thailand.

Without question, the world situation is troubled and uncertain. New trouble spots can erupt with little or no warning. Our policies must take account of the broad global context and we must recognise that Australia's security is bound up with the strength of the Western alliance. We obviously benefit from the security which this alliance brings to us but at the same time we must shoulder the responsibilities which it entails. All of this is part of interdependence and whether we are talking about threats to world peace and security, or about problems of world poverty, or about the slackness of world trade, the growing interdependence of the world must be seen as fundamental.

I would like to say here that the development of multiculturalism in Australia in recent years has helped us enormously as a community in gaining the wider understanding which the successful management of interdependence will increasingly call for. I believe it is a tribute to our responsibility and compassion as a community that Australians have felt involved in tragic events in other countries and have given practical effect to these feelings as shown by the massive public responses to appeals like those for Kampuchea, for Southern Italy after the earthquake, and for Poland. The same concern is equally apparent in the willingness of hundreds of young Australians to respond to an appeal to go as teachers to Zimbabwe. Interdependence is real and in managing it we need policies which take advantage of the opportunities it creates, as well as minimising the difficulties and dangers which go with it. The growth of world trade provides a compelling illustration of our growing interdependence, of the advantages it can bring as well as its impact on key areas such as employment.

It was the rapid expansion of trade in the post Second World War period that was a mainspring of rapid world economic growth that supported the growth of employment opportunities, and of real living standards for countries at all levels of development. Between 1963 and 1970, while the volume of world output grew at an average annual rate of 5.6 per cent, the volume of world exports grew by 8.6 per cent a year. But during the 1970s, the growth of world output and exports both significantly slowed and as a result unemployment started to get worse. It is particularly worth noting in this regard that between 1973 and 1978 , exports from developed to developing countries rose at an average rate of over 20 per cent. How much worse would unemployment problems in developed countries now be without that trade? We must also recognise a further aspect of interdependence-that other nations are taking an increasing interest in our economic and trade policies. Others rightly expect us to be good neighbours, to play our full part in promoting the continued orderly growth of world trade as responsible members of the international economic community. It is plain that the growth of trade, and the growth of interdependence more generally, increasingly exposes a nation's economic system to influences from outside its own borders. Our own increased interdependence with the rest of the world has been highlighted by the quite violent economic fluctuations which have been a characteristic feature of much of the last decade.

Each surge in the price of oil has led to a crisis which caused the growth of world trade to slacken and Australia has been affected in a number of ways by both the oil price shocks and by the slackening of trade. There was obviously renewed interest in the exploitation of alternative sources of energy and this has given Australia opportunities. But the slower growth in world markets has affected our exports and any dip in commodity prices due to unfavourable conditions overseas is plainly going to have an impact on Australia. Even before the first oil price increase in 1973, inflation had become more or less endemic in most industrialised nations. Excessive growth of government spending and inappropriate use of deficit financing played a major part in this. The oil price increases compounded these problems, making growing unemployment and growing inflation the order of the day. Even then, most countries did not recognise what was needed in terms of restraint of government spending, in terms of firmness of monetary policy and in terms of wage restraint. Although there are now signs in a number of countries of a determination to pursue more economically realistic policies, natural economic processes have run their course. In Europe and North America, economic growth has virtually come to a standstill in the last two years and unemployment is high, and rising. In France and in the United States unemployment is 8.5 per cent and in the United Kingdom it is 11.7 per cent.

By the second half of 1982, total Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development unemployment is expected to rise to 28.5 million people, compared with just over 21 million in 1980. In these conditions of virtually no growth and rising unemployment, overseas inflation rates are falling. The OECD inflation rate is now under 10 per cent and falling, a reduction of three percentage points below the 1980 rate. The United States inflation rate fell from 12.4 per cent in the 12 months to December 1980 to 8.9 per cent in the 12 months to December 1981, and the British inflation rate fell from 15.1 per cent to 12 per cent in the same period. Perhaps paradoxically, sluggish growth and falling inflation have been accompanied by some of the highest interest rates, both real and nominal, that the world has seen. This situation stems from a number of factors.

The situation should be seen against the background that interest rates rose less rapidly than inflation during the 1970s. Real interest rates were negative for a substantial part of that decade. And while falling inflation rates in some countries are a cause for optimism, financial markets are not convinced that the underlying problem of inflation has been solved. The present situation has been aggravated by an unfortunate mix of policies in some countries. Budget deficits have been allowed to soar and the resulting pressures on the money supply have been kept in check only with exceptionally stringent monetary policies.

Sluggish growth, low business profits and high interest rates have in turn interacted to produce stagnant investment and continued economic recession. Overseas markets are growing very slowly, if at all. International commodity prices fell 20 per cent in the year to the last September quarter. Australia's farmers are experiencing generally flat or falling prices along with rising costs and they are also subject to quotas and restrictions of many kinds in international markets. Over the last year or so, and partly reflecting some of the factors I have been referring to, there have also been some significant shifts in the world oil situation. At the present time, world crude oil supplies are more than ample to meet demand but oil prices are still very high. The future levels of energy supply and energy prices are full of uncertainty. Our economy is inevitably constrained, and increasingly constrained, by its interdependence with the rest of the world. We cannot but be affected by factors such as the present slackness in world demand and the high cost of funds, nor can we avoid being affected by the protectionism which strikes at many of our exports, especially our farm products. And it is important for us to be aware of the very real dangers that are created by increasing protectionism in other countries during a time of world recession.

Associated with these influences has been a rapid growth in our current account deficit, squeezed profitability for our export industries and some reappraisal and deferment of resource projects. But investment is still moving ahead strongly. We cannot afford, as a nation, to try to ignore overseas developments or their inevitable influence upon us. What we must do is develop appropriate responses. We must be ready to react, ready to adapt, especially to fundamental changes in the world economy, while minimising the undesirable effects of unwelcome influences. In so doing we need policies which lay solid foundations for future growth, which will allow us to take full advantage of the renewed growth overseas which must occur at some time and which will carry us through the interventing period of world downturn no matter how short or long it may turn out to be. In particular, we must prove ourselves reliable and competitive suppliers. We cannot afford to price ourselves out of world markets, or earn ourselves the reputation of being incapable of meeting conractual commitments because of poor industrial relations.
The Australian Economic Achievement

When we look at Australia's present position in the light of our economic achievements over recent years, it is plain that great advances have been made and a strong foundation laid for the future. Although we are a trading nation, and despite the continuing slackness of world trade over recent years, we have swum against the tide. I believe that in the current circumstances, when the facts of interdependence plainly make our position increasingly difficult, our determination to succeed through far-sighted and sustainable policies will be seen as right. It is an undoubted fact that as a result of our policies Australia has prospered in recent years while the rest of the world has been stagnating. Private enterprise has prospered and Australia has benefited. To be sure, in a troubled world economy, we have had valuable resources to exploit and profit by. But that did not make success certain, for the opportunities we had could have been squandered. Possession of resources is only the first condition of prosperity. Another necessary condition is sound government policy and there is no denying that the policies we have followed have created the conditions in which private enterprise has been encouraged to take the lead in exploiting the opportunities on offer. The confidence required for investment to go ahead has been created and, as a result of this turnaround, the living standards of Australia's families have been improved and we now stand ready to grasp the opportunities which will inevitably lie ahead for us.

A consistent assault on inflation has been essential in creating an environment in which private enterprise could plan and invest with confidence. The sustained restraint which has been imposed on government spending which has been virtually unrivalled throughout the world has been indispensable to success. The interests of all Australians require that this restraint must be maintained along with giving proper emphasis to priority needs and concerns. The Budget deficit has been pulled back from almost 5 per cent of gross domestic product to less than 1 per cent. The Commonwealth has eased the pressure on domestic capital markets by curbing its own borrowing requirements and we look for support in this endeavour from other levels of government. Action has been taken to promote industrial expansion and encourage the growth of productivity and there has been a concern for the competitive position of Australian industry.

While success with inflation has been vital, successful, non-disruptive management of the exchange rate has also been vital. Secure and improved access for our products has been sought on established markets, in the United States of America, Europe and Japan and Australian exports have been helped to make significant gains in new and expanding markets, especially in Asia and the Middle East. Industry has been helped by initiatives to encourage industrial research and development and by an accelerated depreciation allowance. Industry has been given due notice of change where reduced levels of assistance are desirable. To avoid delay in putting in place the stable policy foundation on which industry will be able to plan in the longer term, the general reference on tariffs was brought forward.

And when we look across a wider range of concerns, there is cause for pride in what has been achieved.

I shall mention just a few areas in order to provide a broader perspective from which to view some of the challenges which lie ahead. In relation to defence, important steps have been taken in the policy of making sure Australia has an up to date, balanced and effective defence force, including the acquisition of the FA18 fighter aircraft, of the British 105 millimetre gun, and of the aircraft carrier Invincible; and we need to be aware that strong capabilities contribute not only to national security but also to regional stability and security.

In international affairs, consistent expression has been given to Australia's concerns and actions such as our efforts in relation to the issues of world poverty, our decision to take part in the Sinai peacekeeping force, and our contributions through the Commonwealth have helped to build Australia's reputation as a forward-looking, outward-looking and reliable nation.
In the area of tax avoidance, determined measures have been consistently applied-measures which are really biting into this anti-social industry.

In the field of legal reform, the Human Rights Commission and now the freedom of information legislation-the first that will come into place nationally in a Westminster system-are effective measures to meet important community concerns.

In the field of environmental protection, the declaration last year of the new section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park gave further clear expression to the concern for the preservation of our environment which is so widely felt in the community, especially among young people.
In education, the issue of giving our young people the skills they need is being tackled and the increasing emphasis on technical and further education is an important element in this.

Families, especially those with low incomes who received little assistance from the old rebate arrangements, have been enormously assisted by the family allowance scheme which was introduced several years ago and family allowances were substantially increased for larger families from last January.

In the area of social welfare, the automatic indexation of pensions has given income security to a very significant number of people in the community and assistance has been extended to particularly needy groups, such as pensioners facing high rents and sole parents on low incomes.

It is obviously important that governments work to advance the wider opportunities and way of life which Australians want as well as working to secure and improve the material living standards of Australia's families. I believe that as a result of what has been achieved, Australia is now facing the future from a position of comparative strength for there is great underlying strength in this economy and, as I have said already, we are well placed to take advantage of future opportunities provided we work hard to maintain our strong position.
Challenges and Problems

But it is not only opportunities which lie ahead although they will surely come . As we look ahead, as we form our expectations for the future, we plainly need to recognize that there are also problems and challenges. It is our task to identify them, to explain them, to address them realistically and, having done that, to seek the co-operation of the community in coming to terms with them. One thing which is plain at the present time is that a fresher and sharper breeze is blowing through the markets of the world as our industrial competitors , faced with their own situation of no growth and unemployment, restructure their industries, as they improve their productivity and efficiency and as their inflation rates fall. When this is added to the fact that many markets are, if anything, shrinking rather than growing, it is clear that we shall have to fight harder to sell the exports on which our economic development depends.

This harder competition from overseas comes at a time when there are some problems on our own doorstep. Plainly, inflation remains at the forefront as the principal threat to this economy because while much has been achieved in pulling inflation back, there are substantial inflationary pressures in our economy at the present time.

Demands for higher wages and shorter working hours have been contributing substantially to these pressures. And in Australia's present situation, there can be little doubt that excessive wage rises and damaging strikes are placing economic progress at serious risk. It is imperative that we recognise as a nation that wage rises which are beyond the capacity of the economy harm everyone and benefit no one. They cause higher inflation, they threaten our ability to compete on world markets and they create more unemployment. There is no doubt that wage restraint in the next few months is vital to us all for further wage increases at this time on top of the wage and shorter hours settlements of the last six months are beyond the capacity of the economy and time is needed to absorb the increases which have already taken place.

Let me add that there is plainly a continuing need for an appropriately firm monetary policy. In present circumstances, with a weakened balance of payments and strong inflationary pressures, there could be no thought that the money supply would be allowed to expand to accommodate inflationary wage settlements. It is vastly important to us all that demands and expectations should be matched with economic reality as it now is both internationally and domestically. Whatever else may be arguable, there is no doubt that our overall level of economic growth places clear limits on the sustainable real wage increases which can occur.

We must never forget that everything, including wages, has to come out of what Australia is producing. Further limits on wage increases are imposed by the claims of needy and underprivileged people to share the benefits of prosperity and investors also have their legitimate claim for profits, which are the basis of the further investment on which future growth depends. As I have said on many occasions, Australia would benefit greatly from rational debate on the proper balance between these respective claims and I believe that such a debate could have a most valuable impact in helping every section of the community to decide what expectations are reasonable, what claims are legitimate and which demands ought to be moderated.

I turn to the industrial front where the level of strikes and industrial disputation is plainly a matter for the most serious concern. The Government is addressing the situation with some important legislative initiatives as part of an ongoing concern with reforming industrial relations. First among these initiatives will be the provision giving private employers a right of stand-down in strike situations to bring about a better balance in the bargaining position of unions and employers and to equalise their responsibility before the law. We believe that this measure will help to bring home to unions the real cost to the community of strike action and that it will help bring a degree of balance to the negotiating process. The second initiative is designed to put renewed vigour into efforts to achieve a restructuring of unions more in line with the needs of a modern Australian economy and to move away from a system rigidly tied to craft -based unions. And the third proposal, for voluntary unionism, seeks to protect the basic right of ordinary average Australians.

The Commonwealth is also addressing a number of industrial relations issues in co-operation with the States. Important concensus was reached at the recent Premiers Conference and labour Ministers have already met to consider options to facilitate handling of demarcation disputes and the development of a complementary industrial relations system. In considering the problem of demarcation disputes, the objective must be to protect both employers who are harmed and unions which are attacked.

The Premiers have also agreed to work with the Commonwealth in efforts to seek agreement with unions and shipping interests along the lines of the recommendations of the Crawford report, and to reduce the level of industrial disputation in the maritime and waterfront industries. Thus in co-operation with the States, and through our own legislative initiatives, we are taking a positive approach which should remove some of the hurdles in the path of industrial peace and bring a greater sense of responsibility into industrial relations.

In addition to the threats to Australia's economic well-being posed by wage demands and industrial disputes, there are a number of other issues which are of great concern to the community which need to be explained and addressed with balance and realism. Home ownership is one issue which is causing very considerable concern in much of the community and nobody wants Australia's high level of home ownership to be damaged. The issue is complex. There are three inter-related problems: The availability of funds, the high interest rates which currently prevail, and the high cost of houses, especially in some cities. At the present time, the Government has this issue under close review and the Government will in due course announce the policy changes it believes are necessary.

Taxation is a further issue of great concern to the entire community and I want to reaffirm that it is the policy of the Government to make further income tax reductions when it is economically responsible to do so. The present tax levels concern the Government as they concern many people in the community and it is important to remember the major taxation reforms which the Government has implemented, including initiatives such as the doubling of the rebate for dependent spouses which has taken place, the deductibility of superannuation contributions up to $1,200 a year for self-employed persons and others not covered by employer-sponsored schemes, the abolition of death duties, and the tax rebate for health insurance. The cost to revenue-and I think this is not generally understood-of these initiatives alone is well over a billion dollars a year. It is important, when the community considers taxation levels, to be aware of a number of critical factors-the implications for the Budget of an aging population, the need for increased defence expenditure, and the need to pull back earlier Budget deficits drastically. Consistent with factors such as these, the Government's commitment to lower taxes and greater spending power is clear and we shall continue to follow those policies which provide the only basis for sustainable tax cuts.

I have sought to draw the House's attention to some of the major factors which need to be taken into account by the Australian people as we look to the future and seek to match our expectations with reality. Many of the issues which we are facing are complex. Many of the problems do not offer easy solutions and the right balance between competing claims is in many cases difficult to find. But, of course, it is not unusual for a situation to exist in which expectations are greater than can be satisfied, in which different groups within the community are making claims which are inconsistent with each other, in which some claims can be satisfied only at the expense of others, in which some short term aims conflict with longer term objectives. It is easy for people in pursuing their own objectives to overlook the claims of others and put at risk the source of the future well-being of everyone in this country.

The objectives of the vast majority of Australians are plain. As a nation, we seek rising standards of living. We seek more dollars in taxpayers' pockets. We seek an increasingly compassionate society. We seek wider opportunities and greater scope for people to develop their talents. We seek greater security for all our people. We seek increasingly efficient public institutions. We seek the conservation of our heritage and our environment and much more as well. All of these objectives are consistent with each other and a balanced policy approach commits us to pursuing them all. But we plainly cannot pursue all or any of them as fast as we would wish. Indeed, in times of economic difficulty and stagnation overseas, we may be committed to pursuing them far more slowly than we would wish because one thing which is vastly important is that in pursuing these objectives, we cannot afford to destroy economic growth itself. Without growth, all our other efforts and objectives will come to nothing.

It is significant that Australia's growth rate in the last two years has been almost twice the OECD average and it is significant that the OECD predicts a growth rate of over 3 per cent for Australia in this calendar year against an OECD average of just over 1 per cent. There is growth in this economy but we cannot take the future for granted. In a situation of international uncertainty and world economic downturn, where our own growth is held back by the no-growth situation of other economies, we must surely accept as a community the need to avoid putting at risk the present strength of this economy. In dealing with these issues, it is imperative that we weigh up our own claims and expectations against the kind of growing Australia which we want to build for our children, considering both in the light of the real opportunities which are open to Australia in the interdependent world in which we live because only in that way can we reach responsible conclusions on the decisions which lie before us both as individuals and as a nation. I present the following paper:
State of the Nation-Ministerial Statement, 9 March 1982.

That the House take note of the paper.
