SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —With strange and irrelevant flair the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) described his speech as a speech to the Parliament on the state of the nation. Whatever it is, it is not a description of the state of the nation. It is, by its content, by its style and by its presentation, bland, unctuous and complacent but totally irrelevant to the great problems facing Australia today. Admittedly times are difficult. They have been made much, much more difficult than can be ever justified by Fraser Government policies. But there are no solutions in this address to the nation. There are no apologies for the damage which has been inflicted on Australia and Australians in the past six years of the Fraser Government.

SPEECH.PARA: We find in the course of the address that a new offender has been discovered as being responsible for our economic problems-the Australian public. Their fault is that they expect too much. We find that another offender has been discovered- the world. The world will not respond to their expectations. There is only one cause, one fault responsible for the problems of this country today-it is the Fraser Government. Scourge the Fraser Government from office and we will have taken the most significant positive step towards remedying the problems that confront Australia today.

Four weeks ago the Prime Minister was given an opportunity to speak to the Parliament, to defend his Government's policies, to explain what it was he is about. It has taken him four weeks of anguished labour to produce this statement . Only he could convert a mountain into a mole hill. What has happened in the intervening period? The Prime Minister has been smoked out. He has been smoked out by the by-election in Lowe. He has been smoked out by the State election in Victoria. He has been smoked out by the incipient mutiny in his own ranks. He has been smoked out by the jockeying of Lynch, Howard and Peacock, all wanting to replace him. He has been smoked out by the conflict, the contradiction and the downright disagreement with what he stands for by his Minister Carrick and his back bencher Groom. This is a government in disarray. The Prime Minister not only does not have the confidence of the community; he also does not have even the confidence of his own party.

Have we ever witnessed in the history of this nation a situation where a seat, an electorate traditionally safely Liberal, has been handed across to the Opposition by the declaration of the Prime Minister? He will not stand up and fight. Can there be any more clear confession of the acknowledged failure of the Government in economic management? The fact is that the Prime Minister is giving away Lowe because he does not have the confidence, he does not have the self- respect, to get out there and defend the Government's policies. That is because they are not defensible. There have been too many wasted years in this country under the Fraser Government, a description immortalised by Sir Billy McMahon, one of the people closer to the Prime Minister than most people in this country or the Parliament. He knows the Prime Minister; he knows what he is talking about.

The self-indulgence of the Prime Minister this afternoon is repudiated by the public record-not by the Opposition, not by the trade unions, not by the taxpayers who are wincing under the load of the highest taxation bill ever, not by the home buyers who are being forced to put their homes onto a collapsing market and suffer losses, and not by the hordes of people who are being disadvantaged day to day, year in and year out, by the stubborn persistence of the Fraser Government with policies that have taken us nowhere but backwards.

Let us listen to what the newspapers have had to say. The Government does not listen to the ordinary people, the Opposition or anyone who might have an axe to grind. After all, that would take too much time. It would involve 14.75 million Australians. The Australian stated: 'Black day for jobs, housing and exports'. The Melbourne Herald stated: 'Interest shock: Up again'. The Sydney Morning Herald stated: 'Survey points to a gloomy Australian economy'. The Melbourne Age said: 'Outlook bleak on jobs, trade'. The Canberra Times stated: 'Gloomy year for industry'. The Sydney Daily Telegraph said: 'Lynch stirs hornets nest on pensions'. The Liberal-National Country Party Government has to be going bad for the Murdoch newspapers to criticise it.

Let us look in more detail at what has been said about this Government. The Prime Minister told us today that this Government is better equipped to handle the difficult times which are ahead of us. Dr Peter Sheehan of the Melbourne University on 26 January this year stated:
The unique opportunity offered by Australia's resources boom is being thrown away by inadequate economic policies, high interest rates, tight money and increased wage inflation.
The Age of 29 January stated:

This Government has portrayed itself as one with the answer to inflation. That claim is now doubtful. The Government will talk--Mr Howard is an expert at it, almost the Minister in charge of Bad News--of singular circumstances, accidents, special events. All such talk misses the point.
The Sydney Morning Herald survey of banks and other economists a few weeks ago concluded:

After six years of Fraserism, the major economic problems remain as intractable as ever and probably are worsening . . . The potential from the opening years of the resources ''boom'' have been largely squandered.

The Fraser Government has a record of excellent opportunities which have been squandered and lost. The community pays the price. The Prime Minister, through his state of the nation address, declared that the Fraser Government is the Government for hard times. Certainly it has had more experience with hard times in the post-war period than has any other government. It has been practising for the last six years. Australians have had to suffer as a result of it. The Prime Minister blames it all on the world. He says the problems will be intensified by the condition of the world economy.

Let me put a few simple propositions to the Prime Minister and members of the Government. If the rest of the world sets the pace and the direction of the economy in this country, as the Prime Minister declared today and as the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has declared on other occasions, let the Government answer this: How come petrol prices are not to go down as they are in the rest of the world? How come interest rates are not to go down as they are in the United States of America? The Treasurer has declared repeatedly in public and in the Parliament that we have high interest rates because they are high in America. He has said: 'We cannot put them down because they are high in America'. We now find the Government is equivocating. It is to look for another scapegoat. Petrol prices are going down elsewhere but the Government, through its greed, wants to keep the price up in Australia because it wants to hang on to the revenue which it grabs from ordinary Australians as the highest taxing government in this country's history. Interest rates are going down in America. The Government will keep them up here, in spite of its fictitious alibis in the past, because it has become the mouthpiece for the financial institutions in the banking world in this country. It does not give a damn for home buyers, small business, the small farmers and a host of other people who are being racked by the interest rate charges which apply in this country today.

The Prime Minister has said that we have done better than the rest of the world and that the rest of the world sets the standard. Let me raise a few factual propositions for the Prime Minister from the statistics of the organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. The Prime Minister has said that we have done better than the OECD has done in recent years. He has said that the rest of the world sets the standard. In the major seven OECD countries unemployment averaged 5.5 per cent between 1976 and 1981. The total for the OECD was 5.5 per cent. For Australia the figure was closer to 6 per cent. We did not do that much better after all. The Government is using Phil Lynch's principle of using rubbery figures when in trouble. Consumer prices in the major seven OECD countries went up by less than 9 per cent for the same period. The total figure for the OECD was a little over 9 per cent. For Australia consumer prices went up by a figure approaching 11 per cent. How much better is the record of this Government? If the rest of the world sets the circumstances for this country, why did we not do as well as the rest of the world?

Growth, which is important, generates wealth, determines people's living standards and what government and the private sector can do. For the major seven OECD countries growth increased by over 3.2 per cent. For the OECD in total it was a little better than 3 per cent. Australia was struggling to make 2.7 per cent. Let us understand something. In the last half of the last decade the industrialised countries of the world had the intervening redemption after the collapse of the 1970s economic recovery, reducing unemployment and effectively reduced inflation. This was not achieved by the Fraser Government. All we got was more of the same-the same sort of punishment, the same sort of bankruptcies and the same sort of unremitting toughness for households in this country.

Why did we go the wrong way if the rest of the world sets the target? The Prime Minister, of course, is seeking to set the scene. He will try to condition people to accept the proposition that it is all beyond this country; it is all beyond his Government. I would agree with the latter, no matter how simple the challenge. The fact is that the Government cannot blame the rest of the world. Domestic conditions generated by Fraser Government policies, overviewed by the Prime Minister himself, are responsible for a far greater level of damage to this country now, and will be in the future, than world conditions, no matter how difficult, can be blamed for.

Inflation is increasing in this country not because of world conditions but because of the Government. The Government has increased charges for health insurance. It has increased costs for essential commodities by way of indirect taxes. It has increased petrol prices. In this country we have the highest real interest rates of any indutrialised country in the world. So the Government is not satisfied with imposing on Australians the highest tax burden which they have ever had to bear. It inflicts on them the highest real interest rates of any of the industrialised countries in the world. Petrol is too expensive because of Government greed. If the Government were to reduce the price of petrol in line with the reductions by suppliers which are taking place world wide, Government revenue would go down by $112m and profits for its generous bank rolling backers in the corporate sector would go down by $22m. The Government will not instigate either. We have one of the highest tax bills in the world. This year in income tax we will be paying 25 per cent more in that one area alone than all of the tax revenue that was collected in 1975.

The Prime Minister rails about industrial harmony but he is the Leader of the Government. He is the architect of the Government's policy of industrial confrontation. How genuine and consistent is the Government? A few weeks ago the Prime Minister asserted to the community a commitment towards working to establish industrial harmony. He correctly recognised that there was too much conflict. In the period since then Sir Billy McMahon has retired from the seat of Lowe and there is to be a by-election. We suddenly find that we are back to where we have always been-when in electoral trouble, confront, assault and abuse the trade union movement and try to create division and distraction in the community. His Government is responsible for unemployment rising again. It is sheer nonsense and a shabby fiction to come into this House, as the Prime Minister does, and suggest that there are at work elements which are released from outside this country and which are beyond the control of this nation. I repeat: It is a difficult time but there is no shortage of will and commitment by the people of this country to confront these difficult times and to overcome them as they have confronted and overcome difficult times successfully in the past.

The crisis rests not with the Australian people but with the leadership of the nation under Malcolm Fraser. One cannot expect people to sit back and remain indifferent when every week that goes by, through some pretext or other, through some snide device or other, the Government is whittling away their living standards. The living standards of the average family today would have to be increased by $20 a week to give it the same real disposable spending power that it had in 1975. The people know it and they resent it. They will try to re- establish their living standards when they can see-as I will come to in a few minutes-the privileged groups in the community doing so well and when there is nothing but distress for them.

The Prime Minister says, with that grand- iloquence which rolls off his lips very much as a steamroller moves over a bumpy road, that the living standards of Australian families have been improved. That is like trying to sell snake oil to a literate audience. It is a fake. I will tell honourable members what has happened to living standards in this country under the Fraser Government, the taxing Government, the highest taxing Government in the history of this country. These are the sorts of things it has done. There has been a $10 a week drop in living standards because payments to private health insurance funds have effectively been imposed as a private tax on average families. There has been a $20 a week increase in repayments on the average housing mortgage because interest rates have been skyrocketing, and they will rise even more. There has been, or will have been, with the full package of the Government's indirect taxes, a $5 a week increase in the cost of living because of that package. There has been a $15 a week increase in the cost of living in petrol taxes because of the Government's taxing policies. There has been a $15 a week increase in personal income tax for the average income earner. If the average income earner, proportionate to income, paid the same tax that he was paying in 1975 under the scales that I introduced then as Treasurer he would be paying $15 a week less. There is some of the evidence as to how people's living standards have not been just eroded away but hacked away in a brutal and unremitting way by the Government's policies.

If one takes the statement we have before us as a literate exposition of what the Prime Minister is dedicated to, the national management of this country is built on economic waffle. Let us look at some of the promises we have had. As recently as 12 months ago the Prime Minister said, and I quote him exactly:
The Government's success in winding back inflation has been a precondition for the substantial progress in reducing interest rates.
He must think he can do it with magic mirrors. In November 1977 he said:
Interest rates have begun to fall . . . they will keep falling . . . Once the election is over, we will start to move in the consummation of a 2 per cent reduction in interest rates.
He went on to declare a fall in interest rates on housing mortgages. That never happened. They continued to go up. He stated.:
We will fully index personal income tax for inflation over 3 years.
He would prefer to forget about that. He declared in 1975:
We will maintain Medibank.
That is one promise that the Fraser Government could not keep. I give this commitment now: That is a promise which we give and we will keep it for it. In 1975 the Prime Minister said:
We stand by our commitment to abolish means test on pensions.
Then, of course, we have the most fetching undertaking of all in that campaign:
I'd like to have a government which people can trust.

All of those promises and more were solemnly given and crudely and cynically violated. The problem with the Prime Minister is that he has no more credit at the public bank of goodwill and trust when he asked to be taken on his word. His performance is against him.

If I could adapt the immortal words of Alex- ander Haig-admittedly used in another context-this Government is run by a bunch of duplicitous bastards. Eighteen months ago we were told by this Government that constantly makes and breaks promises that we were on the doorstep of a golden age. The mineral boom was about to take off. Let us have a look at what the record shows. The Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony), the man responsible for this belief, encouraged people to believe that there would be a boom. In July last year he said:
We are in the midst of what has inevitably but unfortunately been called a resources boom.

I am certain that . . . what is occurring right now will lift our economy significantly, and permanently, on to a higher growth plateau opening up better and more wide-ranging possibilities for our society . . .

What happened to that boom? We heard today from the Prime Minister that there is an extraordinary level of investment in business. But what about the ordinary people, the little people, the people out in the suburbs, the people who are conducting small businesses which are the backbone of this country, which really are innovative and competitive because these people cannot shore themselves up against the forces of the economy. What about the small farmer? Why are they not sharing in this wealth that the Prime Minister is always talking about? The Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick), when speaking on this issue, said:
We are dealing with the prospective resources boom in Australia . . .
The resources boom in Australia comes about for two reasons . . . Secondly and most importantly the resources boom comes about . . .

I just stress the words 'resources boom'. We were told that all we had to do was to sit back in a comfortable chair, strap on our safety belt and our crash helmet and we would take off to the biggest boom that was ever going to occur. What has happened in less than 12 months? August was the last time when the Minister for Trade and Resources declared that we were about to take off into this new Eldorado. There can be only one explanation-that the Government botched it again, that once again it snarked the economy. Lewis Carroll could just as easily have scripted the economic strategy of this Government. If I may, for light diversion, quote one stanza from the 'Hunting of the Snark' which really sums up more effectively than anything I have come across what government economic strategy is:
But the principal failing occurred in the sailing,
And the Bellman, perplexed and distressed,
Said he had hoped, at least, when the wind blew due East,
That the ship would not travel due West!

That is what is wrong with the economy today. The Prime Minister talks about world currents but he takes us in the opposite direction when they are in our favour; and now he is saying, when they are not in our favour, we will have to go in that direction.

We are now witnessing the lastest search for scapegoats, for the people who will have to take the blame for the Government's failures. We have seen a long list of them before. They have been the trade unions and government advisers, they have been the Public Service and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. You name them, the Prime Minister has thought of them. One would have thought that he had exhausted all possibilities, but there are new ones coming up. I refer to the Budget deficit. We heard today the mea culpa of the Treasurer (Mr Howard), with his George Washington hat on back to front. I started to declare then, and I declare now on the basis of the reliable information that has been conveyed to me, that there is only one credible explanation for that mea culpa. It is simply this: The Public Service, particularly the Department of Finance, has made it clear that it will not take the blame for what it knows to be a Government failure. It has declared that the information about the blow out on the deficit has been available to the Government not for weeks but for months. For all that, the Prime Minister, in a rather craven way, has sought to impugn the integrity and the ability of the Public Service by saying that the Government is suddenly overwhelmed; it is inconceivable that such an event could have occurred, that the Public Service maintains constant monitoring over what is happening with regard to expenditure and revenue and regularly advises the Government of the process of these things. What happened is that the Prime Minister, again caught out on economic management, with the deficit blowing out by more than $1,000m, looked around for a scapegoat and concluded that he had not done the Public Service over for a while, it was muted by Public Service Act restrictions, so he thought he would put the boot in there. He came a cropper. The Public Service, or some people in the Public Service, were prepared at a pinch to go public on this matter if the record was not rectified.

Then there is the other group of scapegoats, one of the most dependent groups in our midst-the pensioners. We now understand quite clearly that the Government intends to move, at what it regards as a propitious moment, to introduce asset testing on pensioners. It is all very well for the Prime Minister to say that there is no proposition before him, pushing it to one side of the table in order to make sure that it is to one side. But we know very well that in the months ahead the intention that has been frequently declared by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) to reintroduce this sort of asset testing will be consummated.

What are the facts? The facts are that the payment of pensions as a proportion of the payment of total income support benefits has gone down. It was over 67 per cent of the total in 1974. It is less than 55 per cent today. Secondly, the total welfare income support bill has gone up very largely because within that total proportion the money going to the unemployed, who are the casualties of the Fraser Government's policies, has gone up some four times from a little over 3 per cent to nearly 14 per cent of the total. Let me put that another way, a simpler way. If we had full employment in this country today we would be saving more than $800m on unemployment benefits, enough to increase the age pension by $9 a week. The pensioners are not at fault.

Again, it is being argued that by the turn of the century there will be a far higher proportion of people who will be of retiring age and eligible to draw on the pension. It will go from about 10 per cent to over 13 per cent. That is an irrefutable fact. But what is equally irrefutable is that that happens because we are becoming an aged population. The proportion of dependent young at the same time will go down, and by a much greater proportion. The consequence overall is that, in terms of the income support bill and the general welfare support bill that the Government will have to sustain, there will be no net addition to that burden.

Let us kick right out this nonsense, this fiction, that it is all the fault of the pensioners, that there are millionaire pensioners who are getting the pension, and accordingly all pensioners who have some sort of modest savings salted away should be subjected to a particularly inclement means test. How sincere can a government be, anyway, when it is talking about austerity at the margin, which is vicious in its impact on the more dependent people in the community, and only a fortnight earlier it blithely entered into the purchase of HMS Invincible, or, as it will be called by the Minister for Defence, HMAS Irresolute? It took long enough to get here; it took long enough to get a decision. We are to pay $500m for that. In spite of all the problems that it will create for the defence budget, in spite of all the fiscal problems that it will create overall, and in spite of the problems that it will create on our external balance of payments, the expenditure of that sum is no problem; it is for defence! But when it comes to ordinary people who are struggling and battling, who are having a very difficult time of it in Australia today, the Government wants to pinchpenny even more.

How is the Government-this businessman's government that knows how to run the corporate affairs of this country, if I may use what I regard as an objectionable analogy but the sort of thing that conservatives like to draw on when they are talking to a local progress association-handling the economy? If this country is well run, it will not be run into hock; it will not be run into a level of debt externally which creates extraordinarily difficult problems. This Government was the government that declared a virtue of avoiding overseas borrowings in 1975. I do not know whether the facts are recognised, but they are fairly startling: Within a few weeks, we shall have an overseas debt in excess of $5,500 million. We shall have, to back that up as currency assets held overseas, no more than $800 million. No business undertaking would try to run its affairs with a borrowing ratio of 80 per cent or a 20 per cent asset backing .

When we went out of government, as Treasurer I presided over a situation in which our overseas indebtedness was reducing and was below $1,000 million, in which our overseas reserves exceeded $3,000 million in foreign currencies-a very healthy situation. It has all been squandered away. The per household debt to pay for this overseas borrowing-borrowing overseas is quite unwise, with consequences that can be quite dangerous at present-has risen six times to over $1,200 million. I apologise for all the figures, but they ought to go on record. This is supposed to be the businessman's government which operates according to prudent fiscal principles. It does not do that. It is reckless in the way in which it prodigiously borrows overseas.

Again, if one looks at what is happening on the money markets, one sees where the confidence is. In more recent times there has been a big shift in where the money is going. It is not going into the finance institutions, where it can go out as longer term investment, going out in turn for longer term investment in the development of this country. It is increasingly going into the short end of the money market. Fixed deposits, certificates of deposit, have increased by some 21 per cent the amount of liquidity in that area. The amount of liquidity that is generated from what is called M1, trading banks cash and so on, has increased by less than 6 per cent. So the Government can look at an average figure overall and say, 'We are sticking to our target of 10 per cent', but when one starts disaggregating it and analysing it one sees therein the seeds for enormous and sustained economic instability.

It means, in a nutshell, in economist terms, that no one who is informed in the money markets believes that interest rates will come down, that the smart money is investing in hedging on the short term market expecting that rates will rise- and they will rise. They will rise after the Lowe by-election and after the Victorian State election, and they will rise in Australian savings bonds by at least one per cent, which means that they will rise on housing mortgages by at least one per cent, which means that there will be even more distress in that area in the community.

Can one invest any confidence in the businessman's government, especially when there is a man such as Sir Phillip Lynch in charge of industry and commerce? If one had put $100,000 into the share market in blue chip shares the day after the last federal election, today, as a result of the erosion of inflation and the flight of confidence on the share market, one would have an asset holding worth about $50,000-that is, in about 16 or 17 months, the real worth of one's lifetime savings, which one has drawn on through computation from a superannuation fund, has been cut in half. That is the sort of security that the Fraser Government offers.

Why has the Prime Minister not discussed some of these rather critical questions that really undermine confidence and security in Australia? Why did he not discuss in detail the tough time that the home building industry is having, where financial approvals from major lenders are down by 20 per cent in 12 months, where the increase in interest rates of some 3 per cent in the past many months has added $20,000 to the repayments on a $30,000 mortgage? With another one per cent increase, effectively the cost of the mortgage would have been doubled by the Fraser Government's policies. Why did not the Prime Minister, when he evinced, he claimed, some heartrending concern for the poor in our community, discuss the revelations of the Redfern legal services that poor people in Sydney are being forced to pay up to 120 per cent to unsecured fringe finance institutions to borrow enough money to get along from day to day? Why did he not discuss the fact that 280,000 people are homeless, that a quarter of a million Australians are in makeshift dwellings, that 80,000 people are on waiting lists for welfare housing, and that since he has been Prime Minister the net financial allocations for welfare housing to the States have been slashed from nearly $600m to $50m?

The Prime Minister talks about concern about the size of government. It is a fraudulent concern. Since he has been in government, he has trans- ferred items out of the Federal Budget across to semi-government instrumentalities and State governments, where these things have to be funded directly. If one looks at the total spending of the public sector since the Prime Minister has been in government, compared with our period in government when it was an average of a little over 35 per cent of gross domestic product, one finds that it is now well over 38 per cent of gross domestic product.

Government has not been reduced. It has become more intrusive. It has become more punitive, and it serves the interests and expectations of privileged groups . But in the meantime it is ordinary people who are being disadvantaged, who have to pay more for health insurance, who have to pay more for essential commodities, and who have to pay more to drive their cars in pursuit of work, and who have to endure the humiliation of being unemployed for extended periods.

We are now-the Prime Minister did not discuss this-well moved into a nasty credit squeeze. It will intensify in the months ahead. Interest rates will rise. There is a very large shortfall of liquidity needed in the community that the Government just will not cover as its policies now stand. Those policies are too severe and too restrictive. They will do damage to a number of financial institutions and to a large number of small businesses. They will be particularly punitive to households in Australia.

Let me conclude. What all this comes down to is that 6 1/2 years of the worst government that this country has known has been reduced to 10 pages of Alice in Wonderland propaganda. It loftily proclaims about the nation's and the Parliament's need to keep abreast of the great economic events, and how everything would be all right if only everybody was as clever and as sensible as the Prime Minister. But there is not one word of acknowledgement and not a single hint of apology for the fact that the lives and well-being and the sheer hope of tens of thousands of Australians have been screwed by this Government for almost seven years, and for what?

I will tell honourable members what the Government can do. It can cut taxes to boost consumer spending. It can regulate interest rates and directly assist home buyers. It can reintroduce universal health insurance and ease the huge cost burden on families. It can abandon its new sales taxes. It can devalue the dollar. It can help reduce inflation by abandoning Government measures which directly add to price increases. It can co-operate with the trade union movement in a prices and incomes policy. All of these measures are immediately open to the Government if it is really determined to turn the Australian economy around from the severe recession into which it is plunging. In other words, it can stop blaming everyone else when things go wrong and face up to its national responsibilities.

It cannot be positive. It is run by the trade union movement which is its master. It is a puppet of the trade union movement, and everybody knows it. That is why the Australian people will always be concerned about relying on the Australian Labor Party to manage the economic affairs of this country.
The Prime Minister has clearly outlined that this Government has taken a very firm and positive approach to handling the economy of this country under difficult circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) referred to Lewis Carroll. That was appropriate. Lewis Carroll obviously wrote his speech, which was a 'wonderland affair', out of touch with reality and the challenges and opportunities confronting Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Since this Government came to office in 1975 its consistent objective has been to correct the gross economic distortions caused by the former Labor Government and, at the same time, to re-establish a stable economic environment. The record shows that we have been successful in restoring economic growth in Australia. Among the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development economies, Australia has stood out over the past two years as an example of growth and stability. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has stood out as one of the most successful political leaders in Australia's political history, one who is supported totally by all of his ministerial colleagues. I have said that our record has been one of growth and stability. The level of real gross domestic product rose by 3 per cent in 1980-81 and is expected to grow by 3.5 per cent in 1981-82. Inflation rates have generally been below the OECD average in recent years. Last year investment increased by 21 per cent in real terms and in 1981- 82 is expected to increase by 15 per cent.

In the last financial year private consumption rose by 3 per cent and in the current financial year should show a similar rise. It could not have been achieved if we had not, with vigour and determination, pursued policies aimed at bearing down on inflationary pressures; policies involving the restraint of government expenditures and the money supply; policies directed towards the resistance of pressures for excessive wage and salary increases and shorter working hours.

The restoration of an optimistic environment for investment has been one of our prime objectives. Australia continues to attract strong investment from investors around the world. In 1980-81 private investment capital inflow totalled $6,406m-a substantial increase over the 1979-80 level of $1,842m. Australia's continued attractiveness to overseas investors rests squarely on the fact that since 1975 this Government has provided Australia with stability and economic policies based on a firm belief in the free enterprise system.

Of course, as the Prime Minister made clear today, there can be no grounds for complacency. There are some disturbing economic trends, both international and domestic, which must be of concern to the Government and to the country at large . The world economy, which has been growing more interdependent for decades, has been subject to powerful disintegrative pressures, both economically and politically. Foremost among these problems are recession and rising unemployment . In the United States of America, Canada, Great Britain, West Germany and the other Western industrialised countries, the slump is expected to lift total unemployment to 28.5 million workers in the second half of this year. These are the highest levels since World War II. Whether individually or collectively, openly or covertly, protectionism is growing throughout the world and is imposing strains between the industrialised countries and between the developed and developing nations.

In the current decade, world trade is likely to expand almost twice as rapidly as growth in world output, with manufactured goods accounting for some 80 per cent of the increase. The newly industrialised countries will be at same time striving for a bigger share of the markets for traditional manufactured goods in the older industrialised countries.

The United States and the other OECD countries are suffering from sluggish economies and slender prospects for immediate improvement. The current United States deficit does not augur well for future interest rates in that country. The growth rate for OECD Europe is expected to be less than 2 per cent this year . Hard times exacerbate political antagonisms, which feed on economic conditions . In a world so fraught with political and economic uncertainty, it would be foolish to expect the Australian economy to remain unscathed. Australia is not, and cannot expect to be, entirely immune from the difficulties which now beset the major economies. Slow growth overseas must mean less demand and lower prices for Australian exports. Our interest rates are a reflection of domestic inflation, demand for funds and interest rates overseas. They are not immune from the laws of supply and demand. Increased interest rates are a corollary of the higher demand for funds and are necessary both to attract savings and to avoid a rationing of available funds by lending institutions. Despite the very bleak and uncertain international outlook, much has been achieved in economic growth and manufacturing industry performance.

We face the future as a nation from a position of comparative economic strength . But our competitive edge is threatened today by wage increases, the pressure for a reduction in hours and by industrial stoppages. The key issue for manufacturing industry in the emerging economic environment is to maintain and improve international competititiveness so that it will be in a better position to ride out short term difficulties and be able to take advantage of any upturn in the world economy and growth opportunities in the longer term.

This Government believes that a strong manufacturing base is an essential prerequisite to a balanced, viable and independent national economy. The solid gains made by manufacturing industry over recent years reflect the Government's responsible policies towards both industry and the economic management of this country. Our industrial policy is aimed at encouraging industry to restructure and become more efficient, more innovative and more internationally competititive. Our policies have led to a renaissance of manufacturing industry from the intolerably low and declining levels of activity which prevailed when we took office. We have developed a number of specific measures to encourage positively activities that are compatible with our economic environment and endowments, including our highly endowed and skilled work force, our vast natural resources and the innovative and entrepreneurial capabilities of Australian industry. We have clearly stated our belief that, as a long term objective, the Australian community will be best served by a manufacturing sector with a structure requiring minimum levels of government support. Considerable progress has been made in reducing industry protection and encouraging desirable structural change while seeking to ensure that changes are gradual, sensitively handled and within the capacity of the community to absorb.

Many factors will influence the ability of Australian industry to maintain and increase its competitiveness. Among the more important are movements in Australian costs, particularly wages, relative to other countries and international trade pressures. Obviously our cost structure is a major determinant of our international competitiveness and in the present and prospective economic environment undue wage growth would present a serious blow to the Australian economy in two major ways. The wage-price spiral will add further to inflation at a time when inflation levels in other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries are decreasing. If the present upward trend in wages continues, the competitive gains we have painstakingly achieved over recent years will be rapidly eliminated. We cannot afford to let this happen. The sooner the main actors on the age setting stage-employers and trade unions-realise this, the sooner all Australians will be better off. A return to wage moderation is an essential prerequisite if we are to restore our international competitiveness. In that sense the present national wage case will have a vital impact.

International trade pressures can be expected to increase over the next decade, as I mentioned earlier, with pressure on labour-intensive industries, in particular, likely to continue to intensify. These pressures can also be expected to extend to other industries as some of the industrialising countries in Asia shift their production and export efforts to capital-intensive, skill- intensive and high technology activities. Of course these developments in the Asian region will, at the same time, open up growth opportunities for some industries, particularly those based on our resource and energy endowments and some complementary skill-intensive activities. Naturally in a depressed international trading environment almost every other developed country will also be seeking to take advantage of these same growth opportunities. In order to cope with this intensified international competition Australian manufacturing industries will have to increase productivity faster than many parts of the world.

Since this Government took office manufacturing industry has gone through a period of consolidation and improved competitiveness. Current difficulties and those immediately in prospect can be surmounted. The manufacturing sector's success in restructuring will largely determine its capacity to participate in and contribute to Australia's economic growth during the 1980s. Let there be no misunderstanding: Realisation of these growth opportunities will be be automatic . For the Government's part, we are acutely aware that the industry policies we employ must be as effective as possible in terms of both the needs of industry and their costs to the Australian taxpayer. To that end we are urgently reviewing the major instruments of our industry policy, including the important area of encouraging greater productive investment. Profitability, the adequate supply of investment funds, and capital, market and taxation systems operating to facilitate the necessary growth in investment, are prerequisites for a growth -oriented manufacturing sector. The Government's decisions on the reform of the financial system and on future industry policy measures will have a major bearing in this area.

It is unfortunate that the Opposition, as reflected by its ill-conceived industry policy, has not grasped the realities, both national and global, which are now facing Australian industry. There is no evidence whatsoever in its industry policy that it has learned from its past mistakes. When it was in government the Australian Labor Party took a series of steps which crippled and demoralised Australian industry. The investment allowance was withdrawn, export incentives were eliminated and inflationary wage increases were supported in every form. Australian manufacturers lost then the capacity to compete internationally and 124,000 manufacturing industry jobs were lost in a single year. Now Labor's policies have become even more radical than before. Labor proposes a comprehensive range of new taxes and disincentives to industry and to investment in this country. Unprecedented income tax rates and a wealth tax--

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense. How dare you say that. That is nonsense.

—Does not the honourable member himself believe in a wealth tax? I think he is on record as saying that and he does not disclaim that. The Labor Party proposes a resources rental tax, withdrawal of the investment allowance, specific regulatory action to impede productivity growth and of course strong support for wage increases and a reduction in the working week. At the same time, it gives implicit support for many of the industrial stoppages which are taking place in this country. These proposals would lead to the gradual demise of the private sector of the Australian economy. The simple fact is that the Opposition does not have an industry blueprint to lead this country into the 1980s. The Government, for its part, is committed to a vigorous, free enterprise economy with incentives for achievement. I am confident that, with the industry and economic policies of this Government and with the support of all sections of the community, Australia's growth potential can and will be realised during the decade ahead.

He is now looking for an overseas alibi to absolve himself from seven years of failure in Australia. But contrast that with what he said in 1975 when he was on the political make. He said:

I do not believe that men and women are governed by inexorable events beyond their control. When political leaders say the present situation cannot be helped , that it is part of the world situation, they are expressing the futility of their own leadership.

That is what was said by the present Prime Minister in 1975. What sort of humbug is being proposed to us today? We are told that our situation is being caused by the problems of the international economy.

In this statement, this piece of political graffiti, what do we find? Under the heading 'The Australian Economic Achievement' the Prime Minister talks about strong foundations laid for the future. What strong foundations have been laid for the future? We have had one of the lowest growth rates of any industrialised Western country. He said that as a trading nation 'we have swum against the tide '. Why would we not swim against the tide? We are selling things that are in short supply, products such as wool and grains. The only reason there has been any possibility of investment in the minerals area is because we have been selling an oil replacement material to Japan. We have been selling steaming coal and we are gearing up to sell liquefied natural gas to Japan. If it were not for the fact that the Japanese Government, not the Australian Government, wanted to diversify away from the Middle East oil we would have no growth prospects in minerals. Mount Goldsworthy, Area 'C' and Marandoo are still on the drawing boards in Japan and will not start because demand is not there for the product. Demand is there for steaming coal and for LNG. The growth in 1976-77 was 3.1 per cent; in 1977-78 it was 0.4 per cent; in 1978-79 it was 4.4 per cent; in the first half of 1980-81 it was 4.3 per cent and in the second half it was 1.2 per cent, giving an average of 2.9 per cent. The average for the whole period is 2.7 per cent. Compare that with the performance of the United States of America, Japan or West Germany which over that period had growth rates double that of Australia.

Look at the other strong foundations laid for the future. When Labor left office 4.9 per cent of the work force was unemployed, 300,000 people. Now 437, 000 people are unemployed, 6.4 per cent of the work force, plus 400,000 in disguised unemployment-that is, people who do not bother to the register. It is more likely that 12 per cent of the work force in really being affected by unemployment. The number of bankruptcies has increased 170 per cent under the Fraser Government. That is what honourable members opposite call strong foundations laid for the future.

Then, of course, we get to the great preoccupation-we will hear more garbage from the Treasurer about this when he follows me in this debate-the constant assault on inflation. The rate of inflation is now running at 11.3 per cent. If we played the dirty tricks the Liberals played in 1975 and multiplied the last quarter, the December quarter, inflation rate by four-this is the sort of antic they got up to when Labor was in power-we would have an inflation rate of 17 per cent. If we use these sorts of figures-if we use comparable figures and compare like with like-the people opposite are now presiding over the highest quarterly inflation rate in Australia's history. The total for the year is 11.3 per cent. It is now well ahead of the rate for countries in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. The Prime Minister has always prided himself on having figures lower than those of the OECD. The Treasurer has frothed at the mouth, for three years or five years-for however long he has been Treasurer- telling us that Australia has an inflation rate below that of members of the OECD. The Prime Minister damned himself in his speech today when he said:
The OECD inflation rate is now under 10 per cent and falling, a reduction of 3 per centage points below the 1980 rate.
Our inflation rate is now onto 10 per cent. We are on the way up, not on the way down. The Prime Minister went on to say:
The US inflation rate fell from 12.4 per cent in the 12 months to December 1981 , and the British inflation rate fell from 15.1 per cent to 12 per cent in the same period.

What are we doing? Our inflation rate is not falling. It is on the way up. By the Government's own record, by its own statements, our inflation rate is going back up. So much for the assault on inflation. This speech is an assault on our intelligence, and the Government well knows it. So we will not hear any more bragging from the Treasurer about where the inflation rate is going.

Another one of the great lies of the speech by the Prime Minister is the statement that the living standards of Australian families have been improved. What a piece of political nonsense that is. The average Australian family would need an increase of $20 a week in income to enjoy the same standard of living that it had six years ago. Look at the situation in respect of taxation. This is the highest taxing government in Australian history. In 1980-81 tax receipts represented 25.5 per cent of gross domestic product. The average during Labor's time in government was 22.2 per cent. Tax paid by the pay-as-you-earn taxpayer- that is the ordinary wage and salary earner who is paid at the end of the week and who is not able to fiddle the system-has increased by 101 per cent since Labor left office although his wage has gone up by only 72 per cent. Tax paid by the non-PAYE taxpayer has increased by only 56 per cent but his income has increased by 94 per cent. So the burden of tax falls all the time on the PAYE ordinary wage and salary earner.

Of course, the motorists cop it. All the motorists who are driving home from work this afternoon will know that the Fraser Government has raised $3.5 billion in petrol tax this year. We should remember that it costs $1 a barrel to produce Australian oil and the Government makes us pay $30 a barrel for the privilege of using this product. When Labor left office the amount was $264m. The Government also raises $500m in sales tax. The list goes on. But the greatest consideration is this: On the present Budget assumption, next year-that is the year beginning 1 July this year until 30 June next year-tax collections will rise by $5 billion . Yet the Treasurer will stand up and say that they cannot give the country a tax cut because the Senate might reject a $330m sales tax Bill. The Government cannot give a tax cut although tax will rise by $5,000m in the next financial year. In the latter part of the year people on average weekly earnings will be inflated out of the 32c tax bracket up to the 42c bracket.

We had a promise that interest rates would fall by 2 per cent. They have now gone up by 3 per cent. Repayments on a $30,000 loan over 25 years have increased by $15 a week or $60 a month. This is the sort of burden which the Fraser Government has laid on the Australian people. But the Prime Minister has the temerity to say that the living standards of Australian families have been improved. That is the statement he makes in this so-called state of the nation address today. The wages argument just shows the futility of this Government. On page 8 of the statement the Prime Minister says:
. . . there could be no thought that the money supply would be allowed to expand to accommodate inflationary wage settlements.

In other words, they have no wages policy. They are just going to screw all the growth out of the economy, screw the money supply down to make sure that wages cannot increase. The Prime Minister went on to say:

In other words, they argue it both ways-that they will not expand the money supply for wage settlements; if they do not expand the money supply there cannot be any business activity; if there is no business activity they cannot hand on wage increases. What sort of logic is that? We know what this Government is all about. It has no philosophy; it has no policies. It is afraid of prosperity. Every time there has been any growth in this country it has stopped that growth and has tightened up the money supply. We are now being affected by a dramatic credit squeeze. If we look at the Australian Financial Review any day of the week we will find institutions offering 17 per cent for two-year debentures. At what rate are they lending that money? They are borrowing at 17 per cent and are lending at 20 per cent, 21 per cent and 22 per cent. Who could make a business pay when paying 22 per cent interest on borrowings? Who could build rental accommodation or housing on a rate of 22 per cent? That is the money that developers borrow. That is the money that keeps business oiled and running. It is no wonder that there is no activity.

As the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has said, this year growth in Australia will be less than 3 per cent. If one takes the investment phase of mining out of that-that is about the only thing holding it up-growth in the domestic sections of the economy is virtually nil. There is no activity. The whole economy is being brought to a standstill. The share market is collapsing. The value of shares is being wiped away. Interest rates will go up again after the Victorian election. The Treasurer had us on at the last Federal election and kept them depressed. He said that interest rates would not rise, but they did after the election was over. They will rise after the Victorian election. All activity will come to a halt because this Government will not expand the economy. It will not take a chance on growth. Whenever there has been any growth such as that which occurred during the first half of 1980, when we had 4.7 per cent of non-farm domestic growth product, the Government has choked it off. In 1980 the Government said: 'We have too much growth'. It lopped off the head of the growth and we were down to 1.6 per cent for the second half of the year.

The Government is afraid of prosperity. This is too young and too vital a country to be left in the hands of these economic clowns who would be flat out raffling a duck in a pub, much less trying to manage the Australian economy. We have had seven years of the same Fraser formula for the Australian economy and we have had an average growth figure of 2.2 per cent a year. On that basis, with rising inflation, rising interest rates and rising unemployment the Government ought to do the honourable thing and go to an election. Give us a chance to let the public adjudicate. We will have that chance on Saturday in Sydney. We will win Lowe and defeat the Government. We want a chance at a Federal election.
