TALK.START.PARA: —The abuse of the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) is as unoriginal as are his analogies. The statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to the House this afternoon is a realistic and sensible assessment not only of the economic circumstances in which Australia finds itself in the world at present but also of a number of other policy challenges which face this country at present. I certainly welcome the opportunity of saying a few things about the economic situation of Australia and also about the alternative economic philosophies which are paraded in front of the Australian people at present. If politics is anything, it is always a question of comparing alternatives. I for one and we on this side of the House will never lose the opportunity of asking this Parliament and the Australian people whether they believe in the present circumstances-circumstances which were spelt out in a very sober and cogent way by the Prime Minister-whether they want to change horses and whether they want to put back on to the treasury benches the people who were there between 1972 and 1975 but more particularly, the people who, being more contemporary, espouse the economic philosophy of people such as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis).

SPEECH.PARA: There has been quite a bit of talk during this debate about the influences on Australia of world economic circumstances. I have never said and nobody on this side of the House has ever said that what we do by way of domestic economic policy cannot influence in some way the international sources at work in the Australian economy. We did not say that in 1974 and we do not say that now. What we did say then and what we do say now is that it is quite impossible for this country to isolate itself completely from world economic circumstances and pressures. What our domestic economic policies can and will do is either aggravate or reduce the dangerous effects of those influences. Our criticism in 1974 was not so much of the disruptive state of the world economy but rather of the extent to which the policies of the then Labor Government aggravated and encouraged-through the expansion of the money supply, the expansion of expenditure, encouraging the wages explosion and following policies of high deficit-the influences on the Australian economy of the events that were then befalling the Western industrialised world.

Just as those policies then aggravated and compounded the difficulties that Australia faced, so too would the policies of high deficits and lax monetary policy compound the difficulties which we now face. Does anybody imagine for a moment that with an American deficit approaching $100 billion we would not have higher rather than lower interest rates if we adopted an alternative economic strategy? Does anybody believe that if a Leader of the Opposition and an economic spokesman, who were in favour of letting the money supply go, were put on the treasury benches it would bring down the levels of interest rates in Australia? Of course, interest rates in Australia now are very high. They are uncomfortably high. They are at levels which are causing concern and difficulties to army thousands of Australians and Australian families. The answer to the problem is not to imagine that by some economic magical trick it will go away. There is no way in the present world economic environment, particularly with the level of American interest rates, that Australian interest rates can fall now or in the immediate future.

The Leader of the Opposition made a lot of play about comparisons with the United States of America. He said: 'Interest rates are falling in the United States. Why are they not falling in Australia?'. Just because there is one fall of half a per cent in the prime rate charged by a number of American banks, as was announced this morning, the Leader of the Opposition like some impulsive puppy, says that our rates have to follow them down. Has he forgotten that the current prime rate in Australia for large overdrafts is 16.25 per cent and that the average US prime rate over the last two years has been 17 per cent? The current prime rate in the United States of America is 16 1/2 per cent. Against that sort of background is there any argument at all that the forces that are now at work in the United States economy will lead to a reduction of interest rates in Australia? I have said before and I say again that if over a period there is a sustained fall in United States interest rates then there are prospects that interest rates in Australia can fall. But the proposition that just because there is a drop of half a per cent we, like some impulsive puppy, will follow betrays completely-to use his own expression-the economic illiteracy of the Leader of the Opposition.

Let us never lose sight of the fact that in a debate of this kind we are talking about alternatives. We are talking about alternative economic approaches in a very difficult and hesitant world economic environment. There will be no early upswing in economic activity in the industrialised world. What we need at present are policies that reinforce the fight against inflation and policies that recognise more clearly than ever that it is the size of government and the size of what it takes out of the community that, in the long run, really matter. If we adopted the alternative economic philosophies of the Opposition and if we went for high deficits and larger government spending we would not reduce our present economic difficulties. Rather we would significantly aggravate those economic disabilities. I do not think we should lose sight of that.

Since I became Treasurer in this Government I do not think there has been a time when it has been more important than now to try to keep an appropriate balance between realism about the international economic situation and that characteristic Australian tendency to self-deprecate. Having heard the speech of the Leader of the Opposition and the speech of the honourable member for Blaxland, one would imagine that there was nothing right in Australia, that there was nothing good about the economy and that every conceivable thing that could have gone wrong had in fact gone wrong. He selectively chose some growth figures. He ignored the present. He was not prepared to admit that in 1981 the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development recorded a positive growth rate of only a little over one per cent, whereas Australia managed a growth rate of a solid 3 per cent. He was not prepared to acknowledge that in 1980-81 business fixed investment in Australia rose by 21 per cent in real terms and that we are still expecting a rise of over 10 per cent in real terms this year. Are they the sorts of figures that are consistent with the scenario of gloom and doom that for his own electoral aspirations he would like to believe will fall upon the Australian economy?

The fact is that in many respects the Australian economy has swum against the tide of international economic adversity. That has not only been because of our endowment of natural resources. Of course that has made a contribution. But above that-and this has been borne out not just by our own analysis but by independent analysis-over the last five or six years, by tackling the fundamental problems of controlling the size of the public sector, by tackling the fundamental problems of controlling inflation, by recognising that it is on growth and on the production of wealth that the ultimate strength of any economy must rest, by following those policies, this Government has given this country a competitive edge and a growth edge that other countries have not been able to achieve. We are one of the few countries which, during that period, have been able to reduce their total budget outlays as a percentage of gross domestic product. We are one of the few economies which have managed to bring about a significant improvement in the balance between revenue and expenditure. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) criticised the monetary policy which is being followed in the United States of America. If I have any concern about the conduct of economic affairs in that country, it is not so much about the conduct of monetary policy but rather about the size of the prospective budget deficit. Ultimately, if governments spend more than they collect, they must do one of two things. They must either print the money, which means more inflation, or they must borrow the money, which means higher interest rates. That was the lesson of the Labor years of the early 1970s. It is the lesson that the Western world is having brought home to it at the present time through the size of the Budget deficit in the United States of America and it would be the lesson which would be more cruelly brought home to the Australian people if an alternative economic philosophy were applied, if in fact we were to expand our Budget deficit.

The honourable member for Blaxland lighted upon a comparison of taxation levels in Australia now and what they were when Labor left office. I have never denied that as a percentage of gross domestic product total taxation collections now are higher than they were in 1975-76. They are plain unassailable facts. But what he did not mention and what ought to be mentioned for the completeness of the argument, is that if we add together total taxation collections and total borrowings, it was a much higher figure in 1975-76 as a proportion of gross domestic product than it is now. What that Government was not prepared to do, what it did not have the courage to do, and what an alternative government now would not have the courage to do, would be to face the fiscal and Budget consequences of its own inability to control its expenditure. If we want a real comparison of that governments take out of the community we cannot ignore borrowings. A government that borrows rather than taxes is a government that lacks courage; it is a government that is not prepared to face the political consequences and implications of borrowing for a current generation, but is prepared to load a future generation with a very large debt burden.

The final subject I would like to say something about is one that I think is important. It is a subject that shows up a basic difference in approach between the Government and the Opposition. It is something that we hear a lot about from the Opposition. That is the question of tax avoidance. We hear many speeches from the Opposition about tax avoidance. We hear the Leader of the Opposition and more recently the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), and other people talking about tax avoidance and saying that if the Labor Party were in office, overnight it could wipe out this problem. They suggest that if we had acted on the royal commissioner's report, in one stroke we would have got rid of tax avoidance in Australia. The truth of the matter, of course, is that this Government has done more to wipe out tax avoidance in this country than any government since Federation. The other truth is that right at this moment the double standard of the Labor Party on tax avoidance is revealed by two things. Everybody knows that there are two elements to tax avoidance. There are the fancy, sophisticated, technically legal schemes against which we have taken such effective action and there is the burgeoning cash economy by means of which people evade the payment of tax. Everybody knows also that the most effective way of countering the cash economy and bringing a bit of equity back to the ordinary wage and salary earner to protect him from the scourge of the cash economy is to have a greater reliance on indirect taxation because that cannot be evaded. But where does the Opposition stand on that proposal? Each and every attempt that this Government has made to broaden the taxation base, to place a greater reliance on indirect taxation, with all that implies for eliminating the economic effects of the cash economy, these great opponents of tax avoidance have opposed, criticised and frustrated. The Labor Party will also have an opportunity in a couple of weeks' time when we present some amendments to the income tax law, to prevent the abuse of the investment allowance provisions of that law by certain statutory authorities, to oppose those amendments. The honourable member for Gellibrand, Labor's economic spokesman, says the Labor Party is opposed to the announcement that I made on 18 December. If his words are to be believed, what the Labor Party will do here and in another place is vote against a proposal of this Government which would protect the ordinary Australian taxpayer from losing between $100m to $200m to some of the largest companies in Australia. Is that tax equity? Is that a party that is really committed to fighting tax avoidance? No, it is a party which, like its economic policy, demonstrates a total double standard on that subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not necessary to reply to the Treasurer ( Mr Howard) on this occasion. The target in this debate is the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). Suffice for me to say, in argument against what the Treasurer said about taxation, that he does not have to rely upon the words of the Opposition to see how taxation is affecting people. All wage and salary earners in this country have to do is to look at their pay packets and they will know what impact taxation is having on them and they will know the increased impact it has had since this Government came to power in 1975. They all know the increased amount of taxation they are paying. So it is no good the Treasurer trying to harangue the Opposition. The Opposition is merely expressing the views of the people in the work place. They are carrying the burden. If the Treasurer were serious about it he would put increased numbers of people to work in the office of the Commissioner of Taxation to do the job that ought to be done in Australia in scurrying after the people who are avoiding and evading their taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an incredible debate that we have on our hands today. For the first two weeks of parliament the Prime Minister acted like Harpo Marx. He could not speak and he could not hear anything and he did not want to participate in any of the debates. He suffered great embarrasment nationally. So Harpo Marx has decided to return to the ring at the second sitting of this Parliament by making a statement to the House on the state of the nation. I do not think the statement tells us anything about the state of the nation but it is interesting that the Prime Minister should call it that and come before the Parliament to take part in the debate. On the basis of looking at the statement it seems to me that the Prime Minister would get sunburnt alongside a rhinocerous because of what is contained in the document. Only a man with a hide as thick as that of the Prime Minister would dare to get up in the Parliament of this nation and paint a picture of the Australian economy and its place in the world such as that which the Prime Minister has given us today.

Through successive election campaigns he has made positive statements and demanded that Australians believe him. In 1975 he told us-another famous prime ministerial promise-that it would take him two years to get the economy booming. Since then, every single forecast and every single promise-there are no exceptions-that this Prime Minister has concerning the country's economy has proven worthless.

In 1977, in an election forced on Australia because of total failure to live up to his 1975 promises, he painted another rosy picture and asked Australians to stick with him. In 1980, not much over a year ago, he gave us the brightest picture of all. We were told that a new economy dawn was about to burst and he promised Australians that if they continued to vote for him there were $29 billion worth of resources about to tumble on Australia. These, of course, were all Fraser promises and we know what they are worth. Six years after Mr Fraser's initial promise to bring back prosperity, what is the real situation? He told us he would tackle inflation first. In that six-year period, inflation is down just two points and if his Treasurer's estimates are at all accurate-they are not always accurate, as Mr Fraser acknowledges-that two points will disappear fairly quickly in the coming 12 months. Unemployment under Mr Fraser has more than doubled. Interest rates are at an all-time high, with no indication of relief. Hundreds of thousands of Australians, as a direct result of these impossible policies, are either out of work or suffering from high taxes and high interest rates.

Mr Fraser was one of the loudest voices in 1974 and 1975 claiming that the difficult economic times that Australia faced were in no way connected with events overseas. Having dismally failed all but the wealthiest of his friends in Australia after six years, he is now seeking to blame the international economic circumstances for his pathetic mismanagement and failure. Fraser has failed Australia in goods times. Why should anyone imagine that he will be any more competent in tough times?

In the past, the Prime Minister has gleefully blamed the possibility of a Labor government for slumps in the Stock Exchange. He has claimed that this has been a clear sign that people do not want Labor governments. But the Stock Exchange floors today are just as empty as the words of the Prime Minister. Six years of deceit, false promises and arrant mismanagement have cured them of that. There will be no resurgence of confidence as a result of anything that the Prime Minister told the Australian Parliament today. We can be sure of that.

The Prime Minister is rapidly becoming the only one, even in his own party, who believes what he says about his economic skills and management capacity. When men such as the Treasurer and the Minister for Industry and Commerce-they are not noted free thinkers-start going their own way, it must be very hard to convince even the most sycophantic of his party supporters that there is anything other than rhetoric in anything that he has told Parliament today. He has certainly not persuaded anyone in the country at large.

The speech today is not a speech aimed at advising the people about the state of the nation; it is aimed at preventing a coup in the Liberal Party; it is aimed at preventing the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the honourable member for Flinders (Sir Phillip Lynch) and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) leading a coup which would replace Mr Fraser in his position as Prime Minister. This speech is all about the survival of Fraser because of his poor performance, particularly in the first two weeks of Parliament. To honourable members on this side of the House it seems incredible that anybody in any form of politics would be concerned about the honourable member for Flinders, the honourable member for Kooyong or the honourable member for Bennelong. That would be a nice front row for anyone to be up against. The Prime Minister is concerned that these people are in some way getting together to replace him.

The Prime Minister, of course, is a first-class advocate of duplicity, and because of the way in which he has conducted himself in getting rid of former leaders before him-I refer to Mr Gorton and Mr Snedden-he no doubt recognises only too quickly what the honourable member for Kooyong and the honourable member for Flinders are up to, and he is out to prevent it. But this is not a state of the nation speech. There is no word in that speech about how many people in Australia are living in poverty, how many are unemployed, or how people such as pensioners are supposed to survive. That is the state of the nation that the people want to hear about. There is no word about how many people have their names on the lists of various housing authorities waiting for welfare housing. Has that not got something to do with the state of the nation? Would not one have thought that the Prime Minister, in talking about these matters, would at least have given recognition to some of the enormous human and social problems that this country faces? But there is not a word about them.

This statement comes from a man who uses, for the first time, such terms as ' balance', 'realism', 'honesty', and 'compassionate'. No one in Australia has ever heard the Prime Minister use these terms before. The Prime Minister uses these terms today when it suits him in order to survive, but the same man has set Australian upon Australian like no other Prime Minister has done. He has set the employed upon the unemployed. He has set worker upon worker. He has set sportsman upon sportsman. He has set the wealthy upon the poor. No person has done more to divide the nation with his policies and rhetoric than the Prime Minister has in the last 6 1/2 years. The Prime Minister has conducted a personal inquisition upon all those Australians who did not share the extreme right wing views of himself.

The Prime Minister complains in his statement that perhaps the Australian people expect too much too quickly. But is this not the Prime Minister who told us about the minerals boom? Is this not the Prime Minister who told us that we would be having a government of smaller taxes? Is this not the Prime Minister who told us that we would have a manufacturing industry boom? Is this not the Prime Minister who told us that we would have an overseas investment boom? Why should not people's expectations at the end of the tunnel, when they have been told all these things at the 1975, 1977 and 1980 elections, be greater than what has been achieved by this Government in 6 1/2 years? Why should not Australians, when they are told of all the resources of this country and what a good position we are in compared with other countries, expect better than the people of other countries? Or are we to do what the Prime Minister did today and say: 'There will be 28 million unemployed in the countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, so we can expect that unemployment will become a permanent fixture, a permanent crime in our society'?

Instead of saying that they are going one way and we are going another, which the Prime Minister should have said, he tells us to accept what is happening overseas. If the Prime Minister wanted to give a readily acceptable statement on the state of the nation, he should have said: 'We are going to do something about poverty. We are going to do something about unemployment. We are going to do something about housing. We are going to do something about taxes'. That is what the Australian people require of him. They are not terribly interested in the intricacies of the Liberal Party when their lives are at stake.

If honourable members opposite want to get rid of Malcolm Fraser, for God's sake do it, so that we can go about governing the country. If they want the honourable member for Kooyong or the honourable member for Bennelong to be Prime Minister, they should put him up. But they should not fiddle-faddle around with the Parliament and the lives of the Australian people while they are doing it. That is what this exercise is all about. The Prime Minister did not have the courage two weeks ago to speak in the debate on the economy, but now he has to come in and make a statesman-like presentation about the state of the nation. The Prime Minister, as I say, has split the Australian public. He has set sportsman upon sportsman. As Raelene Boyle, one of Australia's great athletes, said last Friday, who has heard of Afghanistan since the Olympics? No one has. The Prime Minister, who was prepared to divide the nation by stopping the sportsmen and sportswomen of Australia from going to the Moscow Olympics has not said a word since then about Afghanistan. I will tell the House why. It is because Australian exports to Russia have quadrupled in the last five years. Four times as much wool, meat and primary produce is going off to the Soviet Union. It does not suit the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and the Minister for Primary Industry, and all the Country Party hacks, to talk about Afghanistan now because there is no political advantage. There was some political advantage in what they were trying to do previously in splitting the Australian nation.

They have done the same thing in relation to wages. The Prime Minister in his statement today put forward the proposition that the economy cannot stand any further wage increases. He might be interested to know that about 40 per cent to 50 per cent of the Australian work force have already received, at the end of 1981 or early in 1982, rather substantial wage increases through collective bargaining. It is the duty of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, when it gives its decision on the case that is being heard now on the national wage, to make sure that all the people who have not received those wage increases, late last year or early this year, are brought up to date. There is going to be established in Australia, whether or not the Liberal Party likes it, a minimum wage of about $225, and it should go to unorganised labour in the same way as organised labour has been able to achieve it. If the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission were to go along with the Government's submission, it would be absolute lunacy. That is not what the Commission was set up to do. But again, it suits the Prime Minister to try to divide the country.

The Prime Minister then wants us to take into account, as I have said, the fact that things are happening in other parts of the world from which we cannot separate ourselves. But the rhetoric and the vindictiveness of 1974 and 1975 ring in my ears when I see all those faces that were then in opposition. They were telling us that all the woes of Australia belonged to the Government led by Gough Whitlam in those years. They said that all the mistakes that were being made were being made by the Whitlam Government; the problems had nothing to do with the greatest recession the Western world had seen since the Great Depression. Member after member of the Liberal Party or National Country Party got up and said: 'It is all the fault of the Whitlam Government that unemployment and inflation are growing'. But there was no talk then of what was occurring overseas. But now, all of a sudden, the Prime Minister has said: 'Look , we had better cast this responsibility off. We cannot be allowed to carry the fault for what is happening in Australia'. There is one clear sign in this statement. It will be seen as a very sorry sign by people listening to this Parliament or people who become aware of this debate. The sign in this statement is that the Government has no intention of doing anything about the great ills that affect the vast majority of people in this country.

The Treasurer said that all we could do is to speak of doom and gloom. I am telling honourable members opposite that there are thousands and thousands of Australians-hundreds of thousands if one is talking about poverty, tens of thousands if one is talking about people waiting for houses and hundreds of thousands if one is talking about unemployment-who can see nothing but doom and gloom in this country. It is unfair that they should carry this enormous burden, this enormous social crime that is being perpetuated by a government which, since 1975 has consistently set out to represent the more privileged people of this country. That is why more is not done about tax avoidance and tax evasion, because it would catch up too many friends of the Liberal Party in Australia. So the burden must go to wage and salary earners. There will be great changes in this country, as there will be in other countries, because people will not be prepared to tolerate the extremes of the economic order which are occurring in Australia under a Liberal Government. Those extremes will not be allowed to occur in Australia or in other countries. Things could be done and policies could be adopted which would assist in Australia. It is just the arrogance and the aloofness of the Liberal Government that refuses to allow that to happen in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sainsbury Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a very good idea to have a debate on this wide-ranging subject. It has been very interesting for me to listen to the Opposition talking off the subject, talking down the Australian economy and talking down the achievements of this Government. I suppose that is what we have come to expect from the alternative government opposite, which has no policies which would overcome the poverty that the honourable member for Port Adelaide ( Mr Young) talked about. It has no policies to help the average working man. The policies it has only create poverty. Labor policies deal, in a very token way, with people who most need care.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not imagine I will have time to talk about basic ideology tonight but I can say that the Australian Labor Party, when it was in government, never showed that it has a genuine concern for those in need, and it has never shown any capacity to do anything other than manage the place badly. I suppose the best way to sum up the Labor Party's performance is to say that it could not manage a chook raffle, let alone a country.

We have heard, as usual, the personal attacks on the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), a man who has striven very hard for this country in the past six years and who, on the admission of the honourable member for Port Adelaide, knows how to run a country in good times, which I think is something we ought to remember. The past five or six years have been good times in Australia; far better times than we had in the previous three years. As this Government stays in power during the 1980s and as we overcome, gradually and with very hard work, the problems we have in this country, times will be even better.

I propose to talk about some of the problems that we have. I think it needs to be recognised that this Government is prepared to admit that we have those problems and is prepared to tackle them. But before I do that I point out again that the Prime Minister, in his statement this afternoon, talked about not only the internal problems of Australia and the internal achievements of Australia in the past, but also Australia in the world context. I suppose one of the things that he, as an individual, needs to take great credit for is his attitude towards the rest of the world and towards building Australia as a middle nation that can be a force for peace and for progress in the world.

A number of matters relating to our interdependence have been mentioned and need to be expanded somewhat. We have been through a period in which we have believed, wrongly I think, that embargoes and trade restrictions will do a lot of good in terms of protests. I refer to the Olympic Games and the small-that is the way it turned out-wheat embargo in relation to the Soviet Union. I want to put in a strong plea as an Australian for the proposition that trade embargoes do very little good in sorting out any problems relating to peace.

I was most impressed when I spoke recently in Saudi Arabia with senior members of the Government there about some very real fears that that country felt when the United States of America and Australia imposed, for what we saw at the time as very good reasons, an embargo on certain wheat sales to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. I was told most strongly that when we engage in that sort of practice other countries look around and ask whether countries such as Australia and the United States will do that to them. I think we need to remember that it has been part of history that trade has built more bridges than it has destroyed. When I read about America thinking about putting back arrangements with the Soviet Union in relation to the supply of gas, I wonder whether it is a sensible move. It seems to me that if two countries that are naturally hostile to one another-as they are at the moment-can become more dependent on one another it will be all the more difficult for those countries to engage in a war at a later date. It seems to me that the more dependent we are on other nations and the more dependent other nations are on us for supplies of goods that go to ordinary people, the less likely we are to do anything stupid such as going to war. This is a wide subject. I think it needs to be talked about much more.

I think we also need to remember that not only does trade, and our position in the world, have the effect of increasing understanding and the interdependence that leads more likely to peace, but also it is a very practical means of producing more jobs in our country. I know that I have had a lot to say in Australia about tariffs. I have also had a lot to say about the fact that trade, if carried on at the maximum possible rate between countries, increases jobs. I do not propose to go into all the theory of that. We have found, as we exist in this region, that our capacity to trade with people has not only produced more jobs in this country but also has helped to some extent to increase the affluence of the countries with which we trade. I note especially those countries in South East Asia. Through trading with countries like Australia those countries increase their affluence and their capacity to buy goods from us at a later date. The Prime Minister has said a lot about this in the past. He has said it in overseas forums. I hope that as time goes on we will have the capacity to stick a little more to our words on these matters. It is not only good for us; it is also good for those other countries. As I have said, it ensures a greater capacity for the world to live peacefully. I think, as politicians, that is the thing we ought to address as our top priority. We are after all, as politicians, the people who start all the wars. It is up to us to think about how we can stop them.

The Prime Minister has also talked of Australia being a leader in the world in several ways. I think that as an Australian in this period I ought to reflect on just how proud I am that we have been a leader. It is not only that we have been a leader in some of the external affairs type of questions-the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) this afternoon referred in a very complimentary way to the Prime Minister's involvement in the Zimbabwe issue-but also we have been a leader in terms of economic thinking. When one looks around the world at present at countries such as Germany and Japan, which after all has a big deficit problem, and the United Kingdom, which is at present pulling itself away from the brink of the abyss that successive socialist governments led it to, we realise that we led the way. I know that our economic system is not perfect and I know that too often we have not followed our own principles. But as the statistics show, we are moving towards increased prosperity for our people because we are following, just gradually, a policy that is more and more oriented towards a recognition of the individual and the fact that an individual in an Australian context, given the chance to strive, does get on, does see that his family gets fed and clothed and does see that there is a capacity to look after those more in need. But the Labor Pary has to talk down the achievements, has to spread the gloom that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) referred to, has to try to convince the Australian people-I suppose in the context of the Lowe by- election and shortly the Victorian election-that we are not doing well.

I invite honourable members to look around their electorates. Just look at the number of people who have savings in the banks at present. Just look at the people who were able to go on holidays in the last Christmas period, something which a generation ago they could not have contemplated. Just look at the people in Australia with new cars. Just look at the people who have colour television sets and the people who can afford to eat out at restaurants. I am not saying that Australia has the best distribution of income. I acknowledge as the honourable member for Port Adelaide has said, that we do have poverty in this country. But surely a government which has policies that will lead to greater growth, to greater affluence, to more money in the pockets of the people, I have just referred to, is a government that will therefore provide a capacity to look after those most in need.

I repeat that the policies of the Labor Government are more tokenism when it comes to thinking about people in poverty. Labor Party supporters are prepared to run around talking about poverty but the person they are always looking for to pay is someone out there who is making a profit. They are never prepared to put their hands in their own pockets. They are the sorts of people who are always looking for a third party to solve the problems of somebody else. When I look at my supporters in my electorate and see the work they are prepared to do, as individuals who care for people, I feel very proud to be sitting on this side of the House.

I want to comment on one of the matters the Prime Minister raised which I think is probably our greatest internal problem. It is partly psychological and it is partly bred from avarice or greed if you like. In this country there is an alarming capacity to self-destruct. Whenever I travel overseas, which happens every now and again, I return home thinking: Why on earth are we not achieving our potential better? Why on earth do we have to fritter away our potential at such an alarming rate? Why do we insist on eating away at our gains? The other night I was discussing the question of shorter working hours with some constituents of mine in the country. A school teacher said to me: 'You should not talk about shorter working hours. It is well recognised that when we moved to a 40-hour week in the late 1940s people'-I suppose largely those on this side of the House-'jumped up and down and said that the country could not afford it'. This constituent of mine said: 'When you look back you will see that we could afford it'. All that I said to him was: 'If we had not gone to a 40-hour week, if we had left it for another 10 years, the arithmetic tells me we would have been even better off'. The arithmetic tells me that if Labor Party supporters go around the country saying that we cannot afford this, we cannot afford to help these people or to help those people, and that we are charging too much tax, then surely lower working hours without additional production-and initially shorter working hours means that-will mean that we will be that much worse off. It is a matter of plain arithmetic. If the Labor Party is talking about this country doing better, the best thing it could do is tell the unions which are looking for shorter working hours at this stage, whose members want to produce less and somehow have more money in their pockets-which is an impossibility-that they ought to adopt a responsible course. It should be saying: 'You have an option. You will have less by working less or you can have more by working more' . But no, the Labor Party is not prepared to do that. As I said, it could not run a chook raffle. Its management would say that by some magical process people can work less and have more. That is just not on.

In talking about our self-destruct mechanism, why on earth do unions which profess to worry about the employment of Australians do so much to try to destroy employment? Again it is a matter of arithmetic. If wage rises are greater than productivity, if at the same time profit rates-and this is an element in the equation-are at levels which cannot reasonably be dropped, then the money will come out of the pockets of the people who are in work to the extent that some people will be put out of work. It is an accelerating process. If people are out of work it means there will be less demands, and on it goes. That is the circle that I am afraid the Government has found very hard to break out of. It needs the resolve not just of governments but also of the Australian people. I do admit-and I think the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), who is to speak next in this debate, would also admit this because I have heard him say it on radio-that we do not solve anything in this country by straight out confrontation. To me, as an Australian, confrontation is the way to get Australians' backs up. I was most disappointed again to hear the Leader of the Opposition talking this afternoon about confrontation at the Commonwealth Games between white Australians and Aborigines. The Labor Party claims that the present Government likes confrontation but Labor's own policies build confrontation. That is not on in Australia if we are to solve our problems with the unions. The way to solve those problems is by individual Australians asserting their rights against the monopoly unions. Those rights involve the freedom of choice to join a union and the freedom of choice to strike or not to strike according to the individual's conscience, not at the whim of a monopoly union. As I have said in this place before, monopolies, whether they are of governments, companies or unions, militate against the best interests of individual Australians. I just hope that Australian individuals will strive so much harder in the next few years to break those monopoly unions.

We have a long way to go in this country. The Government has a lot of privilege still to remove. In the tariff area we have some of the greatest privileges. We also have some of the greatest privileges in the union area, as I have said, but it will be up to us, it will be up to Australians individually, to strive to find our own potential. I believe it will also be up to Australians to re-elect governments such as this one which has the capacity to govern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Due to circumstances beyond my control I have approximately seven minutes only to speak in this debate. Therefore I wish to be as concise as possible. Very rarely could this Parliament have witnessed such a catalogue of cant and heap of hypocrisy contained in what is supposed to be a prime-ministerial statement. It is very interesting that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) should have started the statement with the plea that we should resile from the cut and thrust of everyday political life. This is passing strange from a man whom I had reason earlier to dub the cutlery man of politics, the man who was born with a silver spoon in his mouth, who speaks with a forked tongue and who does not run out of knives to stick in the backs of his colleagues. If there has ever been a man in the history of this Parliament who has brought about a debased standard of opportunism in the conduct of political affairs it is this man. Whenever the high road of principle is available to him, as I have said before, he avoids it and dives unerringly for the low road of opportunism. Let us look at how that is proven by his speech in the Parliament today.

SPEECH.PARA: One would not know if one had heard the Prime Minister speak that there was such a thing as the problem of unemployment in this country. It does not rate a mention in the statement. What are the facts in regard to unemployment in this country? The Prime Minister talked about the fact that 400,000 additional jobs had been created in the last three years. The facts in regard to unemployment are simply these: At the start of 1982 the number of unemployed in this country was more than 130,000 greater than when this Government took office. This Prime Minister and this Government came to office on the basis of a promise to reduce unemployment, but it has significantly increased.

Let me spend the little time that is available to me in this debate by addressing myself particularly to those areas of the Prime Minister's speech which come more immediately within my areas of concern. The Prime Minister talked about the wages explosion and, as is his wont, has again misrepresented the facts in terms of the period of his office. He chose to say that in the last two years there has been an increase of $13 a week in real terms in average weekly earnings. I ask honourable members simply to take note of what has happened over the whole of the period that this Government has been in office. For the whole of the period from the September quarter of 1976 until the September quarter of 1981, which is the last quarter for which figures are available, the real increase in average weekly earnings is the miserably low figure of 1.8 per cent. That is a 1.8 per cent increase in average weekly earnings over the whole period that this Government has been in office. If we dissect that further, we see just how miserably the lower income sections of the Australian community have suffered. In fact, the lowest 30 per cent of the people comprising the measurement of average weekly earnings, have experienced a fall in real terms in the standard of living during the period that this Government has been in office. If we take into account the impact of higher interest charges, the impact of higher health costs and the impact of a higher burden of taxation, the fact is that not only have the living standards of the lower 30 per cent actually declined but also average families are worse off- significantly worse off-at the end of this period of Fraser Government than they were at the beginning of it.

Let us look at what has happened in the area of wages. There has been an attempt to paint a picture of a wages explosion. In two-thirds of the national wage cases that have taken place while this Government has been in office, the Government briefed highly paid counsel to go into the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and argue that there should be no increase in wages. That has been its position. Whatever the increases in prices or whatever the economic circumstances have been, the Government has argued for no increase in wages. Of course, to some extent that has been reflected in what has happened in those decisions which have led to the decrease in real earnings to which I have referred. What is the problem that we have now in respect of wages? It is very clear, simple and straightforward. In the middle of 1981, the Government abdicated from the area of wages policy, threw up its hands in horror and said: 'Let it run. Give away the idea of any centralised system of wage fixation and let the strong exercise their power'.

As I have had cause to say before, inside and outside of this Parliament, there is one certain thing in this situation. If responsibility is abdicated, and if the philosophy of the Fraser Government that we should leave things to the free play of market forces, which is what was embodied in the razor gang speech of 30 April last year, is embraced, there is one thing, and one thing only, of which we can be certain. That is, that the strong and powerful will exercise their strength and their power will become stronger. In the areas of capital and organised labour, those who are strong and powerful and in a virtually monopolistic position will become stronger. If groups of organised labour have strength and power, they will use it, if they embrace the Fraser philosophy. What is happening in the community at present, directly as a result of the Fraser Government philosophy espoused in the razor gang speech of 30 April 1981, is precisely that. There is a wider dispersion of earnings. On the side of capital, those who were strong are getting stronger and on the side of organised labour those who were strong are getting stronger.

Of course, the people who suffer in those circumstances can be identified. Firstly, I refer to those in the labour force who are either not organised or weakly organised; secondly, those in small business; thirdly, farmers; and, fourthly, people on fixed incomes. Those people are the weak ones who have no power. It is those people who, under the philosophy of this Prime Minister and his Government, are paying the penalty. Those are the people who represent the piteous suffering from the application of the philosophy of this Government. In the minute that is left to me, I want to make one point clear about what can be done in industrial disputes. I refer to remarks that I have quoted before, of Sir Charles Court, who at the Premiers Conference in August last year made the position quite clear. In essence, he said: 'You can pass all the laws you like. You can pass the most diabolical laws, but, unless you have a spirit of co- operation in the community, those laws will be to no avail'. What have we had paraded here today? It has been suggested that we have passed punitive laws and that we will pass some more. Sir Charles Court has told the Prime Minister that that will not work and the exercise of any decent common sense will tell him that it will not work.

Trade unions have made mistakes, and I know that. But let us face up to the fact that they do not have a monopoly of error. Error exists on the part of governments. It certainly exists among employers. The Government should not talk about more punitive legislation and try to delude itself and the community that that will work. It should seek to bring together the trade unions, employers and governments and to let them understand the realities of the problems that exist. If that sort of policy is adopted, we have some opportunity of properly, equitably and fairly harnessing the great resources of this country and ensuring that they are equitably distributed so that no person is living in poverty or unhappiness in this community, as has increasingly occurred during the lifetime of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What this debate on the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) concerning the state of the nation is all about is the contrast between the policies-primarily the economic policies-of our Liberal -National Country Party Government and those of the Australian Labor Party Opposition. It is about alternatives-the choice between this Government's policies and those of the Labor Party if ever it could attain government. It is about relevance and about the capacity of those policies to cope with the increasingly difficult and complex world economic climate that is emerging. The Opposition seeks constantly to cloud and confuse the broad success of this Government's economic policies. The facts are there to be seen and cannot be gainsaid. The runs, so to speak, are on the board. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development pointed out, as recently as January 1982, the following:

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1978, real GDP--
That is, the total production of goods and services in Australia-
has increased at more than twice the average rate for the OECD area as a whole--
This next statement is in association with that statement-
employment has risen strongly contrary to experience in many other member countries.

The fact is that in recent years there have been 100,000 to 150,000 new jobs annually. As the Prime Minister said, 400,000 new jobs have been generated in the three years to the end of last December. It is true that unemployment, at 6. 4 per cent of the labour force in January of this year, remains higher than we would wish, but at least it is fractionally below the figure a year earlier with the number of people seeking full time work also rather less than that of a year before. This was the result of a significant growth in the work force. Nevertheless the point I would stress is that 400,000 new jobs have been generated over the last three years. The great strength in this development has been the upsurge in investment. Investment in resource development has been the dominant force, but investment in manufacturing and other sectors of the economy has been strong also. The real rate of investment last year, in actual buildings and machines, as opposed to money terms, was up in excess of 20 per cent.

What we are experiencing now is something of a slowdown-not a recession-which is attributable, not solely but in significant part, to overseas factors. I refer particularly to the no-growth situation in other major economies, the fall in real oil prices and, notwithstanding all that the Government did to offset them in the last Budget, the continuing high interest rates. One effect of this stagnation overseas is that in some countries inflation is beginning to fall from previously very high levels. On the other hand, the continuing thrust of economic activity in Australia, coupled with the spate of irresponsible industrial action on the part of militant unions, particularly on the wharves, is making inflation in this country stubbornly difficult to contain and reduce below an underlying level of 10 per cent. We concede that that is a problem. We do not suggest that there are no problems confronting this Government. But I say to the Opposition, for goodness sake concede what we have achieved-growth at twice the average rate of the other leading industrial, the OECD countries, and rising living standards.

In contrast, when you-the Labor Party-were in Government you added to the negative influences from abroad. What we have done-and what the Prime Minister is appealing to all Australians for a joint effort to continue-is to limit the impact on the Australian situation of difficulties overseas. The prospective slowdown makes even more critical the importance of containing excessive wage and salary increases and thereby in association with an appropriate exchange rate policy, maintaining the improvement that has been achieved in our international competitiveness. The improved cost position enabled us, as a result of the policies of this Government, to compete more effectively with imports and therefore to give jobs to Australians, keeping Australian factories operating, and to compete in overseas markets which again creates employment and fosters economic activity in Australia. That is what an effective internationally competitive position means and that is what has been achieved by the containment of inflation and the pursuit of appropriate exchange rate policies. This has contributed very significantly from the supply side, to use a technical term, to the strength and growth of the Australian economy and to jobs and the raising of living standards.

The honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) who preceded me in this debate referred to the current national wage case. It is imperative that if there be any increase in wages it be confined to those employees who have not yet had increases. The honourable member referred to the gains that the 'strong and powerful' have already achieved. For example, the metal workers achieved a very favourable agreement just before Christmas. I hope that the honourable member will join me in stressing the imperative necessity that the strong and powerful, to use his words, do not get an increase twice over-once as a result of collective bargaining and again through a generalised wage increase as a result of a national wage case decision. I hope that the honourable member will support me in saying that.

The honourable member for Wills, on the last sitting day before the recess, said a lot about the necessity to introduce so-called job creation schemes. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to Parliament today-this so-called state of the nation speech-was a farrago of falsehood and fantasy. The Prime Minister tried to tell the Australian people that at a time of record high interest rates, record high taxation, the highest unemployment since the 1930s, continuing high inflation, sluggish economic growth, falling living standards and declining home ownership that the Government is doing a good job. Not surprisingly, he was not very convincing. In an attempt to give some credence to his highly implausible claim the Prime Minister focused on the international economy. His reasoning is as follows: Firstly, he said that we are affected substantially by events in the international economy and the growing world recession has therefore adversely affected us; secondly, that nevertheless we have made some substantial gains and are performing relatively well; and, thirdly, therefore the Government's economic policies are appropriate to the present state of the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal with each of those points in the Prime Minister's argument. In regard to the first point, I agree that we are affected by what happens in the rest of the world. Of course that is true. But it is entirely false to attempt to portray international factors as being largely adverse. The fact is that the major adverse factor in the world economy in the last few years has been a positive factor for growth in the Australian economy. I refer to the second oil shock. The second oil shock was the second round of increases in international oil prices which occurred at the end of the 1970s, when a 150 per cent increase in international oil prices followed the quadrupling of oil prices in 1973. The impact of an oil shock on oil importing countries is twofold. Firstly, it affects them in relation to their balance of payments by increasing the size of their import bill and secondly it increases the cost of a basic commodity in the economy and so generates inflation. It therefore forces countries into contractionary policies to keep inflation down and to reduce imports so that they can maintain an even balance of payments. The effect of those contractionary policies is to deepen international recession.

The international economy was already marked by high unemployment before the second oil shock-the first oil shock had brought that about-and also the inability of most governments to control inflation other than by creating more unemployment. The central economic question of our time involves the inability of governments to control inflation except by creating more unemployment. However, that matter was not addressed by the Prime Minister. I will come back to that point later. Thus the situation we have is that further recession resulting from the second oil shock has been devastating for many countries but not for Australia. Australia is one of the few Organisation of Economic Co- operation and Development countries with substantial oil reserves. We are roughly 70 per cent self-sufficient and so our import bill did not rocket up as a result of increased imported oil prices. Obviously that had some effect but we were largely insulated in that regard, at least in respect of the balance of payments. We could have been insulated from the inflation effect, too, except that the Government adopted a full import parity pricing policy for Australian- produced crude oil. That added substantially to inflation in Australia and so the protection which we would have had was obliterated.

Australia was not only substantially protected from the adverse effects of the second oil shock but also it gained from that second oil shock in a most important way. Increased investment in resource development was brought about by the greatly increased attractiveness of our non-oil energy resources, especially coal and natural gas, and also the increased attractiveness of developing in Australia industries which depend on energy resources. The aluminium industry is an obvious example. Our energy resources became more attractive because, with the increase in the price of oil, there was an understandable desire by companies and governments to obtain energy supplies of a non-oil type and also to diversify requirements and ensure access to energy in the future. They looked particularly at Australia, with its substantial non-oil energy reserves, and that resulted in a substantial increase in investment in this country, as referred to by the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Edwards) and other speakers in this debate.

We do not deny that there has been a very strong increase in business investment in the last year and in the current year. Last year there was a real increase in business investment of approximately 23 per cent-a very strong increase indeed-and in the current year we have seen a rise of the order of 10 per cent to 15 per cent. But those increases are very substantially related, and undeniably related, to resource development directly and indirectly. As a result of this large rise in business investment the rate of economic growth has increased somewhat. Not unnaturally the Government seeks to take credit for this but it has little to do with this Government's policy. It has everything to do with the fortuitous rise in oil prices and our legacy of vast mineral wealth. That is why we have this surge of business investment at present. It is not because the Government's policies were so attractive that all of a sudden businessmen rushed into the marketplace wanting to invest but because something happened in the international market which made Australia suddenly a very desirable place in whch to invest in resource developments. Thus, the impact of the second oil shock in Australia has been vastly different from that in most comparable countries. We have been protected from the initial adverse balance of payments effect and we have benefited from the consequential increased business investment in resource development. That increased investment, involving a high level of capital inflow, even enabled us to improve our balance of payments significantly last financial year. At a time when other countries were everywhere facing deterioration in their balance of payments we were able to improve ours because of the inflow of foreign capital associated with increased business investment.

Indeed, as a consequence of the capital inflow we appreciated the Australian dollar by almost 10 per cent. But now, with the second round effects of the increased world recession reducing demand for our exported commodities, our balance of payments is deteriorating and we are being forced to devalue. We have devalued by 6 1/2 per cent so far since August of last year and are likely to have to devalue somewhat more. Nevertheless, as all other countries are suffering these second round effects as well-that is, the induced recession is affecting everyone's exports-we are still relatively much more protected from the international recession than most other countries. We should surely realise that. Trying to say that international factors are so adverse for Australia and are creating the basic difficulties for this country is an absolute deception of the Australian people. We are one of the countries in the pretty unique position at present of being able to benefit from the situation which has been very adverse for most countries of a comparable nature.

The Prime Minister claimed that we have made substantial gains in the period that his Government has been in office. The Prime Minister's speech is full of such gains being made and of better performance in Australia than overseas. In most cases they are a gross distortion of reality, marked particularly by a careful use of base periods to best suit the Prime Minister's case. Let us take economic growth. The Prime Minister points to the last two years and says that Australia's growth is almost twice that of member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. This is substantially true. But, of course, this is because of the completely different impact of the second oil shock on Australia and on OECD countries generally to which I have just been referring. If we look at the last two years we will see that the growth situation in Australia has been better than the OECD generally because of the factors to which I have referred. But if we look at what has happened over the past five years since the Fraser Government took office, 1975 to 1980, a different picture emerges. We see that in that period gross domestic product growth per annum in Australia averaged 2 1/2 per cent but in the OECD generally it was 3 1/2 per cent, which is significantly higher. On a per capita basis, for Australia it was 1.3 per cent and for the OECD generally it was double that, 2.7 per cent. So if we take the period, as far as one can go, under the present Government, we see that our growth rate has been quite poor compared with OECD countries generally.

The Prime Minister talks of the Government's success in regard to inflation. I guess this depends on one's concept of success. The fact is that the annual rate of inflation is now at 11.3 per cent which is well above the OECD rate of 9.9 per cent at present. The OECD forecast is for the inflation rate to go down to 8 1/2 per cent in the middle of this year. So it is difficult to see how we can claim much success particularly as our inflation rate is certain still to be over 11 per cent at that time.

The Prime Minister says that living standards are very important. He mentions increased living standards as the number one objective of the vast majority of Australians. I would not disagree with that. But as evidence of rising living standards he mentions that average weekly earnings are up by more than $13 a week in real terms in two years up to the September quarter of 1981 and that real household disposable incomes have increased by $2.9 billion after tax in the last financial year. In regard to this let me say firstly that his average weekly earning exercise pays no regard to the increase in taxes over the last two years or increased interest rates. It also ignores the fact that real average weekly earnings before tax declined between 1975 and 1979. Thus, if we take a single person on average weekly earnings and look at what happened between September 1975 and September 1981, we see that real after tax income increased by only 1 1/2 per cent in that six-year period. The real after tax income of a person on average weekly earnings with a dependent spouse and two children over the same period-September 1975 to September 1981-declined by 0.5 per cent. So where is this massive increase in living standards to which the Prime Minister points, this thing which is the number one objective of Government policy and of most Australians? It just has not happened. There has not been an increase in living standards for the vast majority of people. Of course, the figures I have mentioned ignore things like interest rate rises which are also important to living standards.

As for the rise in real household disposable income in 1980-81, the Prime Minister understandably takes the one year during his period of office in which there has been a notable rise in the real level of such income and ignores the increase in the number of households in that year. The fact is that between 1975 -76 and 1980-81 real household income per household-one surely must take the increase in households into account-in Australia increased at an average of 0.4 per cent per annum which is a miserable rate of growth. That figure of 0.4 per cent per annum is for all households, not just wage and salary earner households . Where the hell is this increase in living standards we are supposed to be seeing? It just has not occurred.

In regard to housing, the Prime Minister says that investment in dwellings rose by 26 1/2 per cent in real terms between 1977-78 and 1980-81. Again he picks his base carefully. If he had gone back to 1975-76 he would have shown a growth of only 5 per cent as compared with 26 1/2 per cent he got by going up to 1977-78. He is just playing with base years, messing around and trying to deceive people into believing that gains have occurred which simply have not occurred.

I refer to the Prime Minister's argument that the Government's policies are the appropriate ones for our time. With a record like this Government has it takes an enormous amount of gall to argue that the Government's policies are just what Australia needs, particularly as such policies have not succeeded in any country . The monetarist policies that the government has pursued have been disastrous everywhere they have been tried. Unfortunately conservative governments in many countries have applied such policies and in so doing have greatly accentuated the international recession. It is crucial to understand that what such policies amount to is a preparedness to increase unemployment to whatever level is necessary to keep down inflation. It is taking more and more unemployment to keep inflation down. Three per cent unemployment in 1961 kept inflation to zero in 1962. Although we have six per cent unemployment this year we still have an inflation rate of 11 per cent. So we can see that with twice as much unemployment we still have high inflation.

Furthermore, if we are to continue with such policies we need more and more unemployment to keep inflation to any given level. This is the clear trend. So we must ask ourselves how long such policies can be pursued before the fabric of our society begins to crumble. Moreover, it is important to realise that with such policies we can never achieve economic recovery. I say that because as soon as some recovery occurs inflation begins to take off and so the Government clamps down on the economy, recovery is aborted and unemployment increases. If we are concerned to see unemployment reduced we must abandon Frasernomics-the economics of recession and unemployment. What we must do, as the Labor Party is doing, is develop a prices and incomes policy which gives us the only chance to have a substantial non-inflationary recovery. Such policies involve government intervention in both price and income setting in order to achieve a reconciliation of conflicting income claims at lower inflation levels than is now possible. It is important not only that Australians do this but also that other countries do so as well.
