SPEECH.PARA: In times such as this it is obvious that people will be very confused about the economic direction of the nation. To lay some fears at rest let me say this: Members of the Government parties are very well aware of the great concern of families in Australia in making ends meet. We are greatly concerned about the plight of pensioners in making ends meet. There is not a day goes by that members of the Government side of the House do not meet dozens of people in their electorate offices or out in the field, and spend time talking to them about their very personal concerns about the family budget and about the concerns of the aged as they go into a period when their opportunity to influence their future becomes diminished. Obviously their future becomes financially diminished but sometimes it is also diminished in terms of declining faculties. There is no doubt that in the present day and age families are finding it very difficult to make ends meet. When it comes to the end of each week, fortnight and month the family is highly concerned about an increase in salary, tax, interest payments, the cost of groceries and all those things which are absolutely vital in its life. Those concerns are reflected in the representations that are made to members of the Government parties as they are to the Opposition. Similarly, pensioners are finding that the small amount of income which they are able to earn from their past thrift might be nearing the tax threshold and an income testing limit which might affect their pension or fringe benefits. Those concerns are brought back very clearly to members of the Government parties as they are to the Opposition.

In these very difficult economic times it is fair for those people to ask how the Government views these problems. It is also fair for them to ask how the Opposition views these problems and what the alternative strategies might be. The first thing that we do from the Government side is to acknowledge that these concerns are real, that they exist. They are very personal considerations that affect each individual family and pensioner. Nobody on this side of the House will withdraw from that concern or that detailed consideration of those problems . The real question is whether anybody will try to delude people as to whether there is an easy answer. I will look at just a few of the alternative ways of examining this economic problem. People say that it is terribly boring to refer back to the period of the Labor Government. Of course it is. It is always boring to look back about six years.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not boring; it is irrelevant.

—That honourable member for Fremantle says: 'It is irrelevant'. It may be irrelevant to him but it is not irrelevant to many people because the same kinds of differences in approach are here with us today. The greatest cheat that we could perpetrate on the Australian public would be to indicate to families which are finding it difficult to balance the family budget and to pensioners who are finding it difficult to cope with increasing costs that it would be easy to solve their problems.

SPEECH.PARA: What do we have by way of opposing strategies to deal with this problem? On the history of the matter we find that the ALP Government did not have an economic strategy at all. I do not think that anybody has claimed that the Labor Party had an economic strategy when it was in government. I suppose the present Leader of the Opposition is a slight exception to that in that he claims that when he came to the Treasury towards the end of that unfortunate period he was struggling towards some objectives which he believed might get somewhere. I admit that that is a matter of debate.

Generally speaking, the Labor Government did not have an economic strategy. Basically it believed that government spending could be increased indefinitely. It believed that it could accede to wage demands indefinitely. It believe that it had only to let the tax rates increase through inflation in order to increase the tax take. It believed that it was possible to promise all things to all men and women and that somehow in the end the bountiful Australian economy would come good. Somehow the then Government believed that this would happen despite the fact that it was hitting out at investors-anybody who intended to invest in the future of Australia in a productive capacity in businesses that would provide employment and extend the future of Australia for more and more Australians. It believed that it could hit out at those interests and businesses , attack them as being either foreign or people who were only after their own good, and hope that somehow they would continue to support investment and support employment. Of course, that formula did not work. People stopped investing. People from overseas did not want to come in and invest. The labour unions increased their demands on the economy for increases in wages which were beyond that called for by productivity. Generally speaking, the economy got into a frightful mess. We got into a very substantial Budget deficit of $4.5 billion.

The history since 1975-1975 is not all that long ago-has been one of pretty painful recovery. There was an increase in government spending over those three years of the Labor Government of about 10 per cent per annum in real terms, that is excluding inflation. The present Government, to the great disappointment of many of those who voted for it, did not actually manage to reduce government spending. That is something for which people criticise me as a Government member and for which the Government is criticised. People say: 'You promised to reduce government spending. You have not done it'. The present Government, against the advice of the Labor Party and against extraordinary pressure even from its own supporters who do not like government spending being cut when it really comes to the point, has managed to reduce the increase in government expenditure to an average of about 1 1/2 per cent per annum over the six years that it has been in office. That is about the rate of increase in the population. In other words, if one takes it on a population basis, the present Government has held government expenditure flat. Before the present Government came into office government expenditure went up by a real amount of 10 per cent per annum over three years. The extraordinary fight to pull that curve back from a steep increase to a flat curve is well known to everybody. People who vote Liberal and people who vote Labor have complained to Government members in every electorate office about the reductions and cuts in government expenditure. At the same time people have complained about the amount of tax which they are paying and about our incapacity to cut government expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The same people.

—The same people, as my friend the honourable member for Casey points out. Really, what we are talking about is honesty on everybody's part about what the economic sums are. The Fraser Government has had an economic strategy throughout these six years. As honourable members opposite will know, I am one of those who have been quite critical about various aspects of government policy . There were various things that I hoped might happen under our Government which have not happened. But I have to say this: The previous Government did not have an economic strategy; the present Government has an economic strategy. It has not always followed it as closely as I would have liked but basically an economic anti-inflation strategy has been pursued since 1975.

SPEECH.PARA: What has that strategy been? It has been one of control of the money supply, opposed by the Australian Labor Party. It was opposed tonight in the House by the honourable member for Blaxland. It has been a policy of wage restraint, of delaying the introduction of a 35-hour-week in the hope that wage increases would be governed by increases in productivity-a policy opposed by the Labor Party. It has been a policy of control over government spending against the pressures not only of the Opposition and the unions but also, to a large degree, of the Opposition's own supporters-a policy opposed by the Labor Party. It has been a policy of reducing the deficit, of reducing government borrowing and thereby reducing the need for increases beyond a certain amount in interest rates. In other words, it has been a policy to reduce pressures to increase interest rates, and that policy has been opposed by the Labor Party.

The Labor Party has proposed an increase in all government spending and an increase in the size of the Public Service. It has not complained about the current campaign of the Australian Council of Trade Unions on television to increase the size of the Public Service. It has supported demands for rapid wage increases as it did when it was in office. It has taken a benevolent view of what trade unions have been doing in all of the various disputes in which they have been engaged. It has not criticised the Wran model of industrial relations, which has been one of give in and subsequently put up with all the difficulties that that has resulted in. It has been the Hayden social contract model, when no social contract with unions thus far in Western democracy has been proved to work. The Labor Party has had a negative attitude to investment, particularly by people from overseas. It has not encouraged Australians to save to invest in their own resources but at the same time it has criticised foreigners who have been prepared to come in and fill that gap. All of these approaches have been put forward by the Australian Labor Party in opposition to an economic strategy put forward by this Government under great difficulty, often under criticism from its own supporters, and in a world in which we have increasing economic difficulties.

The real question that faces Australia and the real question that faces this House in debate is this. Admitting that things are difficult, admitting that the average family is finding it very difficult indeed to make ends meet, admitting that pensioners are finding it difficult to cope with increasing prices, the question is: Would it be better for the Australian public, for the average family and for pensioners, to reverse the existing policies as advocated by the Labor Party or would it be better to struggle on with the policies and do the very best we can against adverse circumstances? That is the question I put before the House tonight. I challenge the Opposition not just to criticise, not just to say how bad things are, but to answer the charge which is that if we reverse these policies, surely we will all be worse off.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) today was a confession of failure. As has already been pointed out to the House this is a Prime Minister who has been in office for a record term; a Prime Minister who, after a massive publicity campaign, came into office in 1975 telling the people of Australia that the problems of unemployment, the problems of inflation and recession were all domestic problems and were in no way related to overseas economic factors. For this Prime Minister, controlling inflation and providing jobs-let us quote him-'for all who wanted to work' was simply a matter of sound conservative economic management. It was as simple as the campaign theme of the Liberal Party; it was as simple as turning on the lights. That was the simplistic assertion, expensively mounted, lavishly sold, that not only gave the Prime Minister his electoral majority but also gave the people of Australia expectations that were as false as the political prophets who mouthed them.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1975 any assertion that the Australian economy was interdependent with the rest of the world was dismissed by this Prime Minister and by every Minister who sits behind him and by his mealy-mouthed back benchers, who today were reduced to gloom and graven images as they heard the despondent message of the Prime Minister. As far as they were concerned, any suggestion to the Australian economy being economically interdependent could be dismissed as sheer Labor propaganda.

And so we come to today. For years we in this House have lived in a situation in which the Prime Minister, confronted with any economic problems at all for the first five years, was prepared to blame the Whitlam Government, although he had a record majority in both Houses. He had no problems with numbers; he had no difficulties with legislation being held up. He had the game before him and, day after day, confronted with problem after problem, the solution was simple. All honourable members on that side of the House had to do was to get up and say: ' But it was all the fault of the Whitlam Government'. After a period had passed, that excuse was no longer politically plausible. Even the blue-rinsed old ladies who comprised the Liberal Party's State councils and who loved the Prime Minister could no longer regard that statement as having any truth in it at all. He had to find someone else to blame and so for the last two years he has been blaming the trade unions.

Who are these trade unions, these demonic forces that ravage the Australian economy? The fact is that the average Australian trade unionist is the average Australian worker. If he is in a situation in which he is continually fighting to make ends meet, in which he finds his living standards continuously eroded and the only way he can maintain those living standards is by being prepared to resort to industrial action, if he cannot produce increases to maintain his standard of living by negotiation with his employer, then of course he is subjected to this continual demeaning by this Government. When Ministers of this Government talk about trade unionism and trade unionists it is as though they are talking about men from Mars, outside invaders whose only intent and purpose is to destroy the whole basis of the Australian economy. What they are talking about, and they always seem to forget it, is that the average Australian trade unionist is nothing more or less than the average decent Australian who goes to the football on Sunday and whom one might meet at his bowling club--

TALK.START.PARA: —He never goes to union meetings.

—He goes to more union meetings than the honourable gentlemen opposite. Part of their problem, which shows up every time they talk about the trade union movement, is that they know nothing about it, and they do not want to know. But what has now occurred in Australian society is that the Prime Minister has discovered-he has discovered it in Lowe, and he is discovering it wherever he goes in Australia-that the average Australian will no longer accept the prescription that all the faults and problems in Australia are not the fault of this Government but are the fault of Australian trade unionists. So what has happened? The Prime Minister had an opportunity less than a fortnight ago on a motion of censure, which no Prime Minister who operates under the Westminster system anywhere in the world would have refused, to take up the debate and to defend the lack of confidence expressed in the motion, his economic policies and his government. The Prime Minister squibbed that debate. So today he comes in with a brand new statement to the Parliament. What is the new revelation? What is the new discovery of Malcolm Fraser?
—Order! The honourable member will refer to the Prime Minister as such.

—What is the new discovery of the Prime Minister? What new book has he read which has given him some prophetic insight which compels us to consider this statement? He has read something, because what he has now discovered is the converse of what he rejected in 1975. The Prime Minister has discovered the world, and it is the world that is now to blame for the economic policies of his Government. What are those policies?

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the Prime Minister's record of achievement. When the Labor Government went out of office in 1975, inflation was barely above 11 per cent and falling; it is now in excess of 11 per cent and rising. In 1975 the unemployment figure was 310,000 and falling; it is now 437,000 and rising-the highest level of unemployment in the history of Australia. In 1975 the average trade unionist was paying 59 per cent in pay-as-you-earn tax; he is now paying 66.3 per cent. The interest rate on home loans in the last years of the Whitlam Government was 10 per cent and falling. It is now 12 1/2 per cent and rising. If one wants first mortgage money, one is lucky if one can get it at 18 per cent, and one will probably pay 20 per cent.

The attack on the living standards of the average wage earner, the Fraserisation of the pay packet, has meant that the average worker is faced with increased health costs, increased interest rates, and increased costs for basic food commodities and clothing. The average family is now about $30 a week worse off.

The concept of the new federalism-that glib term which was tossed around in the circles of the Liberal Party-has turned sour in the mouths of Liberal Premiers. The Prime Minister, the national leader of the Liberal Party, is now so popular that his Liberal cohorts in his own home State of Victoria have told him that the greatest single contribution that he can make to the return of a Liberal Party Government in Victoria is to stay out of the State. He can go overseas or to other States, but the one thing that they do not want him to do is to go to Victoria.

We have today the spectacle of this Prime Minister reading to us what must be the sorriest statement, which purports to pass for an economic document, in the history of Australia. It is a sad confession of failure. Where in this document are the new promises? Where are the new visions? Where is there hope for the unemployed? Where is there hope for the small businessman who is going broke? Where is there hope for any section of Australian society?

I agree with the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) and those other speakers from the Opposition benches who have said that of course one cannot regard the Australian economy as being able to be cut off from any decline that takes place in other parts of the world, particularly in the Western world. But it is equally true that we are an exporter of food and, given our wealth and resources, an energy-rich country. We are rich in mineral resources. There is probably no nation in the Western world which was better equipped than Australia to withstand the problems of economic downturn or economic recession. All that it needed was effective political leadership. But what I find extraordinary in this document is that the Prime Minister concedes economic depression and failure in Great Britain, and concedes the problems in the United States. But does he learn from them? The economic problems that confront Great Britain and which are dividing English society from top to bottom are postulated on the same economic doctrine as Malcolm Fraser is posing for Australia. It is the same kind of economic nonsense that is mouthed by Mrs Thatcher, the Iron Lady. It is precisely the same kind of economic nonsense that is mouthed by the Prime Minister of Australia. If he continues with that philosophy, what has occurred in Great Britain will occur in Australia. The President of the United States is another exponent of small government, of the private sector, of letting the rich get richer and making certain that the poor get poorer. The economic doctrine of the President of the United States is now a matter of concern in all journals of economic repute in the United States. It takes more than a jaded film star to solve the problems of the United States, and it takes more than a jaded grazier to solve the problems that this Government has created for itself.

What we are now confronted with is a situation in which, looking at the same problems-they are in different dimensions, admittedly-there are gross economic downturns in the United States and in Great Britain-this Australian Government and this group of back benchers that sits behind it are unable to reach a conclusion which any 12-year-old kid studying economics might well reach. That is that when two Prime Ministers and one President are all saying the same thing in terms of economic philosophy and in all of their countries there are grave economic crises and downturns, perhaps the philosophy is wrong. That is not what comes through from this document. The only question is whether he is going to be honourable enough to resign and hand over the reins of leadership or whether he will wait for the people of Australia to say: 'For God's sake go and go quickly so that this nation can start on a course of economic recovery'.

This document is Malcolm Fraser's farewell to Lowe. The only serious political question, on any analysis that anyone in the Press Gallery has now got to make having in mind that there will be no change in economic doctrine-this is what we are all worrying about and putting our bets on-is whether there will be a change in the Prime Ministership. The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) is loose, and even the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party (Sir Phillip Lynch)--

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all running now.
—They are all running. The knives are out. If the Prime Minister thought that he had to worry about the honourable member for Kooyong, let him wait until he has to deal with his own deputy leader.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Mr G.O'H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support very much the statement made today by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). I thought it was a legitimate, honest and sincere expression of the economic difficulties with which this country is faced . Those on the other side who are so vociferous about the statement had better take note of the facts of the matter. It is no use going off and trying to buy cheap popularity piece by piece in the way they are doing it. It will never work . It has always been the Achilles heel of the Australian Labor Party. The last speaker, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding)-I know he will be proud of it and not disappointed-whom I describe as an apology for the left wing of the Labor Party in Victoria, who was sent here so that he could be got rid of from the State scene in Victoria because he was no damn good, had the nerve tonight to accuse the Government of falsity-
—That is a tired old line.

—If the chatterbox will put a thumb in his mouth for a while I will get on with my speech. Nobody on this side has ever, to my knowledge, condemned unionists. We have a very high regard for unionists. What we have no time for are the bully boys. We have no time for some representatives of unions. We have no time for those who make people go out on strike when they do not. We have no time for those who take no notice of the wives of unionists who feel the pinch when their husbands go out. We have no time for those who do not suffer any economic disadvantage when they pull their own union out. We have no time for those sorts of people who want to produce a revolutionary system within this country. We have no time for those who do not see some merit in the continuity of the good life we have got in Australia. That is what we have no time for.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get right down to the point here and now. On the Opposition side today there are-of course I do not in any way look at you, Mr Deputy Speaker, when I say this-those who have had a very great influence in the trade union movement, a very great influence. They come along here, some as the pensioned-off leaders of trade unions and some with, no doubt, an intent to do something to help their country. Some, no doubt, have an intent to help the welfare of the unionists they used to represent. What do they do in this House? What do they do when Wran 's fleet, as I have heard it described by the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Edwards), is tied up off Sydney? What do they do to try to help the country and get those ships going again? They do nothing. They sit in this House and do nothing. Why? Because they are playing their own cheap political game. They do not want to get ships moving. These bully boys I refer to have no regard for the welfare of ordinary, decent Australian people, male and female. That is what the Government is on about and that is why so many pious utterances have come from the other side today.

The level of the argument in the last three weeks has been what? From the other side it has been cries of 'falsity', 'broken promises' and 'liar, liar'. It is a very unfortunate turn of phrase when it is used unscrupulously. There is a deliberate attempt to denigrate and single people out in a most unfair method that I think would not bear any comparison with what happens in any other democratic country in the world today. That is what some of the Opposition members are doing to the parliamentary system of Australia. That is what they are doing to the democracy of Australia today. When I first came into this House many years ago there were some elements of decency and friendship on both sides. That situation cannot persist today when the alternative Prime Minister of this country drives people out of the House when he gets up to speak. He drives them out because he makes unfair, unfounded charges based on gang warfare, based on ' liar, liar, liar' and based on things that do not make this House work. That is a serious matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you know about it?

—If the honourable member for La Trobe stays here for more than three years-I will be very amazed if he does-he might learn something about the proper functioning of this House. Up to now he has learnt nothing.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to deal with four major items tonight. The first one is that, thank goodness for this country, the first Prime Minister and leader of a democratic nation I know of in the free world who saw that the world increase in costs was going to continue was Prime Minister Fraser. Two years ahead of any other country we took a deliberate decision as part of an economic strategy because we saw what was going to happen next and realised that we must cut down on costs if the taxation base in the future was to be such that we would be able to pay our way. That is what we did. Eighteen months or two years later Prime Minister Thatcher came along. Years after that, Mr Reagan came along. This Government, contrary to the oversentimental nature of some well meaning members of the Labor Party, realised that the taxpayers of this country would not be able to pay the bill unless some rationalisation took place.

Do honourable members realise that it took seven years for the Fraser Government, with all the best will in the world, to overcome the deficit caused by the Whitlam Government? This year for the first time we managed to balance the books. What a mighty effort that was and how fortuitous that was, given any blowout that we may see in the Budget. Would anyone say that it was the fault of the Fraser Government that crude oil production in Bass Strait ran into strikes? Are members of the Opposition serious about that? If they are, I would be surprised. Would anyone in this House say that it was the Fraser Government's fault that the world price of crude oil came down and cost this Government revenue? Of course we are pleased about it, but it has cost the Government revenue. Would anyone in this House say that the state of the economy of the United States of America is this Government's fault? I ask honourable members those questions because they are the three reasons why there could be a blowout of the Budget. The Opposition tonight, led by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), has quite unfairly and unobjectively tried to say that those three things are the fault of the Fraser Government. Of course they are not. The big thing I am so pleased about in relation to the 1981-82 Budget is that we were able to budget for a domestic surplus. Thank goodness we did. What did the Labor Party say about that in the Budget debates? It performed left, right and centre on every little pinpricking item and said that the Government should be expending more money. Thank goodness we budgeted for that domestic surplus because it is very important that we did. We have that safety valve that will benefit this nation over not one year but over many years to come.

I am very surprised that with the exception of the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) there has been no appreciation at all tonight of what the Government has been about. I criticise some members of the Opposition today as an alternative government. I criticise them for their lack of economic responsibility. They have not put their minds to the real issues which this country will face in the future. They have not attempted to put their minds to them. I am getting very fed up-as some honourable members may have gathered tonight-hearing what I regard as political expediency flowing from the mouths of the members of the Opposition. It does not do credit to the Leader of the Opposition or his party as an alternative government. Whether in a by-election atmosphere we hold the seat of Lowe or the Labor Party takes it really is a matter of temporary political judgment by people.

I am sure that the honourable member for Lalor, with his great exuberance, will know what he is talking about. I do not know but he may be referring to the world leadership that the Prime Minister has given in the Commonwealth of nations. I am not very concerned about that one way or another but I am deeply concerned about the future of this country. I invite honourable members opposite to apply their minds to the future of Australia. It is not just a matter of additional expenditure here there and everywhere because people are saying that they need more money for this, for that, for the arts and so on. Governments cannot say yes to everybody. It is a matter of looking responsibly at the future of this country and the direction in which it is heading. I congratulate the Prime Minister on his statement. I support it wholeheartedly. I suggest that the honourable member for Melbourne Ports will not find too many chinks in the armour of honourable members on the Government side of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't be racist.

—I think this lead will be a very great asset for this nation in the future. If we were to adopt racist policies-I know that the honourable member did not mean that-then the future for this country and our kids would be very different. I congratulate the Prime Minister very much in respect of that matter which had been brought to mind by a remark of the honourable member for La Trobe . I hope that this Opposition, the alternative government, does not in future adopt an alternative to proper and reasonable debate such as gang warfare, wich includes screaming out the word 'liar', because such a procedure does no credit to this institution and it is no credit to the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the speech of the honourable member for Wakefield ( Mr Giles) had been made in support of any other government but this Government one would have felt some sympathy for him as a supporter of the Government. The honourable members who sit opposite remind me of those figures discovered in an Army vault at Sian in China-a full regiment of porcelain soldiers there to defend the emperor in his tomb. They think as loudly and as actively and they put forward solutions in defence of the Government in about as imaginative a form. The statement today by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is typical of the type of waffle and nonsence that we have come to expect in this Parliament from the Liberal and National Country Party Governments. It almost equates, although not quite as badly, that which comes from the Victorian Government. The Victorian Government probably has only one major achivement-that it has put forward a number of proposals for solving the economic problems but has spent more money on advertising the Minister who put them forward than on the proposals themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: We heard pious nonsense-that is the only way I can describe the previous speech -to the effect that the Opposition should do this and that. It is interesting to note that the Government accepts no responsibility for industrial disputes or other activities which occur under federal awards. The Prime Minister displayed an amazing capacity for failing to recognise responsibilities for national leadership but he has no problem whatsoever in blaming the New South Wales Government, his favourite aunt sally, for those disputes which occur under State awards and especially those disputes which involve State and federal awards. I recall that it was this Prime Minister, as the shadow Minister for Labour and Industrial Relations, who prevented going through this Parliament legislation which sought to solve problems associated with Federal and State awards, problems which could be solved by legislation and on which a report was brought to this Parliament in 1974. Both inside and outside this Parliament we hear Government Ministers making statements about the terrible labour relations in Australia, the lack of legislative authority and how the Government is unable to act, but never, do they mention the role they played in preventing this Parliament passing legislation to deal with industrial disputes resulting from conflict between industrial laws. The Liberal and National Country Parties in this Parliament voted against fixing up problems which have been around since the 1960s as a result of the Moore v. Doyle case, thus creating an enormous number of industrial disputes in this country. Outside this Parliament it was those honourable members who now sit opposite who successfully campaigned against the provision of powers in the Constitution to give this Parliament the right to legislate in respect of wages and prices policies. They lament the lack of powers, they created the problems and they then seek to use those problems for their own political advantage.

The problem Australia faces today and the problem which I think the Western world faces is the lack of credible leadership. Australia unfortunately has no one who speaks on behalf of Australia and Australians. This country has no one who can be looked to as a national leader in whom trust can be placed, no one who can be accepted as meaning what he has said or as being credible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at the last three elections.

—Let us consider the last three elections. Who on the Government side is prepared to stand up and say that any of the commitments which arose out of the 1975 election-and may I mention the most inportant of them, taxation-were kept? The Government promised, firstly, that it would retain Medibank, which is now a standing joke in the whole of the Australian community. The Prime Minister in this Parliament, as the Leader Opposition and as caretaker Prime Minister, having been placed in office by a dishonest act, stated that taxation by stealth was not a policy which could be accepted by the Australian people and that in order to keep governments honest his Government would index taxation, thus requiring governments openly to raise their income tax revenue and other forms of revenue in a manner which could be seen and understood. That is what he said in this Parliament when he was in opposition and when he was seeking election. Of course, income tax has not been indexed fully. In the last Budget the Government at last abandoned even the pretence of indexation. It has said that there will be no further indexation. The reason for this is that the Government does not want to have to acknowledge publicly the level to which it is increasing taxation on the Australian community with the exception of that section of the community which it favours, that is, those people on the 60c in the dollar bracket. They are the only people in the Australian community on comparable incomes who will pay less tax this year than they did last year.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at how the Government fulfilled its promises to the pensioners. In the statement the Prime Minister said that the Government had indexed pensions. How many honourable members recall that on one occasion only a couple of years ago the Government saved $30m in revenue by amending the increase in pensions from twice to once a year? Where in the Prime Minister's statement today, in this state of the nation address, is there anything which will ease the worry of pensioners who in three months' time will have to pay tax on income over $6.50 a week after they receive the increase resulting from the most recent cost of living figures? Where is a statement that the minimum tax level will be raised so that their earnings above the pension will be protected? I refer to another section of the community. There are a number of means tests on pensions but there is one which is the most restrictive of all. I refer to pensioners who are paid rent assistance. Any income over $2 that they receive is means tested for their pension. On the basis of the current tax minimum, a pensioner who meets fully that minimum $2 a week income pays tax on his rent allowance.

That is the extent to which the low income earner is being served by this Government. That is the extent to which the Government is meeting its commitments. The Government talks in totals and in gross figures about climbing social welfare bills. Let us look at the relativity between the social welfare bill now and what it was when the Government came into office. Firstly, the bill for unemployment has doubled in real terms because the Government has failed to do anything to cure unemployment and has openly admitted in this House, in the Prime Minister's statement, that it has no concern for the unemployed of this country.

That is one part of the welfare bill. Another area in which a false extension took place was when family allowances were created. No one objects to family allowances, but what happened was that a deduction allowed under the taxation system was replaced by an entry in the welfare outgoings column. It was a straight transference of money from one pocket to the other. Family allowance payments add to the welfare bill but the abolition of the tax deduction for children has resulted in an increase in taxation but a reduction in tax foregone . The Government is able to say what it wishes about welfare but the facts of Australian life are that under this Government those on the lowest incomes- families with incomes under $15,000 a year, families struggling to pay off a home, pensioners and people on fixed incomes-have suffered a greater loss than that which is generally spread across the whole of the community.

The Government's economic policy is based on depriving those people who work for wages, who have no other source of income and no means of avoiding their liabilities for pay-as-you-earn taxation and consciously seeking to reduce their standard of living whilst transferring additional profit, additional incomes to those in the community who have the most money and therefore are least in need. That is the basis of this Government's policy. It has talked and talked about how it is cutting back on government expenditure and practising small government . But this year this Government, which professes to be a small tax government, will collect in taxes a greater proportion of the total income of this nation and will devote a greater proportion to public expenditures than has any government in history. If the aim of the Government is what the Prime Minister said it was when he came into office in 1975-that is, to reduce government expenditure, to reduce taxation and, as one of those sweet sounding phrases we once heard in this Parliament says, to allow the people to make decisions on how they spend their money-it has been a case of great phrases and great sloganising . The facts of life are that Australian people in general have less money to spend now than when the Government came into office and the Government spends more of their money than ever before in the history of this country. The general community receives less in return because of the incompetence of this Government and because of its penchant for making decisions not on the needs of the Australian community but on the perceived ideological program of a government which is bereft of any conscience and bereft of any sense of integrity in is actions towards the Australian people.

This Prime Minister and this Government have created greater divisions in the Australian community than has any other government in Australia's history. The Government has done more to divide the Australian community than has any other government in Australia's history. In Australia today there are more people than ever before in our history sleeping in the streets, deprived of adequate income and of a roof over their heads and more people whose homes are under threat because of the Government's inability to cope. Most importantly, a nation which is in crisis needs leadership. It cannot be provided by the Prime Minister who made the statement today. He is incapable of engendering trust and of obtaining the trust of the Australian people because he has deceived them on too many occasions. On too many occasions he has told them solemnly that his Government will do this and that. We all remember the promises; they are a legend. Too often he has been found wanting in his delivery of the trust that the Australian people have placed in him.

Australia needs leadership. It needs leadership desperately. It will never obtain leadership from a Prime Minister who believes that the next political trick, the next political deception, the next point scored is a plus for his administration. A Prime Minister who practised the policies of this Government, who honestly put them forward before this Parliament and who was prepared to stand up to the consequences of his policies would earn at least respect even if he did not earn votes. But, of course, the facts are that on each occasion when this Government has been under threat it has made promises that it knew it could not keep, made statements that it knew it could not honour, and has now spent the total accumulation of trust and respect which is due to a Prime Minister and national leader in a government. The only service which the Prime Minister could now place above his own personal interests and in the national interest would be to get out of this Parliament as fast as he can so that we can start to repair the damage that he and his Government have created.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser ) for a concise position paper on Australia today. He has opened debate for all to express an opinion and all will get an opportunity, without needing to interject, I am sure. Whilst he, the Prime Minister, presented a balanced report , the Opposition has given us gloom. The honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes ) has just informed us of the need for leadership. I guess he is of the opinion that it might come from somewhere on the Opposition side of the House. I disagree entirely and I thought I might let him know what the public of Australia thought of that possibility when they were asked about the abilities of the Government and the Opposition to alter the interest rate market as it exists in Australia today. I quote from a Morgan gallup poll published in the Bulletin of 9 February. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, they-
That is, the people interviewed-

were asked: If the ALP was now the Federal Government, do you believe interest rates would be higher, the same or lower? Forty-seven per cent said they believed interest rates would be the same, 14 per cent said higher, 21 per cent said lower and 18 per cent could not say.
In other words, 61 per cent did not think that the Australian Labor Party could do anything about it and 18 per cent were not sure. The article continues:
Forty-eight per cent of ALP voters said interest rates would be the same if the ALP was now the Government compared with 46 per cent of Liberal-National Country Party voters.

In other words, a higher percentage of Labor voters had less faith in their party to achieve interest rate changes than did the Liberal voters. We are talking about leadership. That clearly shows the public's opinion of Labor's rantings about spending more while taxing less. The Leader of the Opposition told us about the good times of 1972 to 1975 and the bad times of 1976 to 1981 and produced the usual statistics. He failed to tell us that the period 1972-75 was when Labor threw a party and took all of Australia out to celebrate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It did what?

—It threw a party. We all had a great time, did we not? He failed to say that the growth figures of 1976 to 1981 that he quoted were heavily retarded by the cost of paying for that party. It is time that the Leader of the Opposition, along with some of his colleagues, particularly the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) discovered how much faith the public has in his rhetoric. The item which I have just drawn to the attention of the House is as important in that regard as any to which I could refer.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Wills chose to quote Sir Charles Court. He had to look beyond his own party for a quotation of note, and chose one by a top Liberal. He did so to substantiate a great political truth, that no law can be effective without public support. I say that no democratic government can lead a reluctant population even to prosperity. The original Australian, the Aboriginal , and our early settlers were unable to generate any sort of standard of living until they commenced to trade internationally.

Australia cannot consume the products of its industries and its resources; it must export. The honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating) told us today that it was just a matter of good luck that we had any trade at all. In one respect I agree with him. Australia has tended to be priced out of international markets as a result of the activities of union leaders who have encouraged workers to reduce production and demand higher wages at the same time. I wonder what the average unionist's attitude would be if one of our champion cricketers walked off the ground after he had made 50 runs, saying, 'That's enough; there is no need for me to make a century any more'; or if a champion goal scorer walked off at three-quarter time, saying, 'I have got my five or six goal total for the day ; that should be enough'. When we stop to think about it, what is the difference ? We are either working for Australia or we are not.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the trouble; you have not thought about it.
—I can tell the honourable member that I have created jobs as a businessman while he has gone around destroying them.
—What did you do to the Aborigines?

—I have employed up to 100 people. Some of Labor's union confederates see the word ethic as a dirty word. We are well aware of the value of human endeavour in the less resource-rich countries. Some of this endeavour is imported to Australia, sometimes by way of refugee boats. An example of Australia's treatment of such enthusiasm was clearly demonstrated recently when a group of refugees found employment in the production line of an electronics factory. The supervisor placed these people-being new-at the beginning of the line, performing a simple task. This soon created great ruction as the part- finished goods were leaving the refugees too quickly and longer term workers were coming under pressure. To avoid industrial strife the supervisor transferred the refugees to the top end of the line where they sat twiddling their thumbs waiting for the product to reach them. That is a recipe for annihilation. Australia's economic performance will match the efforts of its work force. The proportion of total world trade that Australia needs to employ 250,000 people represents a mere fraction of that trade. It need only compete in a world context-not kid itself about protection and about creating jobs, by reducing working hours. Examples available all over the world show that if working hours are increased employment will be increased because the country is made more productive and more competitive.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to some of the hyprocrisies of the Opposition's case, as presented today . Its leader expressed concern for investors in the stock market-the arch capitalists. That is absolutely astounding. He tried to suggest-he has twice done so now-that the average Australian has all of his savings tied up in the share market. What a lot of rot! He is much more likely to have them tied up in cash savings where the returns have at last reached a level which will allow him to live off his savings and retain the real value of his investment. But the Leader of the Opposition did not want to tell us that. He told us a hard luck story about an individual who had invested his sole $100,000 in the share market . He can introduce me to someone like that. I have never met anyone who was so foolish. Perhaps it was a personal experience of the Leader of the Opposition; I do not know. The share market experience has purely demonstrated that there is now a direct profit in lending money; that the capital gain sought in the market is no longer so necessary. When cash lending is no longer attractive, the investor will probably return to the share market. In the meantime, industry can improve the price of its shares by increasing its return on investors' funds; in other words, getting out and making more profits. That will put share prices up. It can do this when it discovers that it must be efficient and highly productive . It will not do it by making wages and hours deals which price its goods off the market. As Australians choose to save their money to gain higher interest income they will not buy this overpriced production. The work force will suffer and the honourable member for Wills will blame this Government for greater unemployment and, I suppose, suggest more Regional Employment Development schemes. He will then, of course, choose to forget his quotation of Sir Charles Court's remarks, which suggest that perhaps people govern themselves to a greater degree than at other times he chooses to believe.

It was not long ago that honourable members received a letter from the Geelong Trades Council. Amongst other things, it called for the Government to increase spending power within Australia and suggested that for this purpose a levy should be applied to our presently ailing mining industry. These people overlooked the fact that the levy had already been applied by a greedy work force which, by an excessive wage and hours structure, had already creamed off money that might otherwise be distributed more evenly in the way proposed. However, at least that money has reached the community and it will circulate.

But what of the other great burden that all Australian industry must bear-the strike? The cost of waterfront strikes this year was estimated to be $550m. No doubt the cost of all other strikes would exceed that amount. The cost of strikes represents a direct, self-imposed extraction of spending power from the Australian economy. The billion-plus dollars to which I have referred can multiply many times as it moves through the system. Through industrial activity the Australian Council of Trades Unions and its affiliates impose much greater control on the money supply than the Reserve Bank ever did.

I return to some of the hypocritical claims made by the Opposition in this debate. It has expressed concern about home ownership levels and home interest rates. Yet it promotes policy after policy aimed at increasing government expenditure and reintroducing the 20 per cent inflation rate over which they presided during their last attempt to govern the country by handouts. Such inflation will affect the cost of homes. If lenders are to retain the value of their investment, interest rates must exceed the rate of inflation. When that happens, do not bother about the price of money because, as in 1975, no one will want to borrow, no one will want to invest in Australia. If Labor's philosophy was really directed to home ownership, why will not the Government of New South Wales sell State houses to its tenants? The Labor Party does not believe in home ownership. Its socialist philosophy sees a home as something to own during one's lifetime and then return to the State, preferably directly but if not, by way of capital gains tax or death duties. The greatest hypocrisy of all must be the recent announcement that the Labor Party will no longer support these types of taxes. I find it hard to decide who are the biggest hypocrites-those who saw the political reality or those who have denied their genuine socialist philosophy and have gone quiet on this issue. They are a disgrace to the socialist cause. I , as a capitalist-an agreed and admitted capitalist-say, thank you very much; but I do not have faith in the Labor Party sticking by its decision if it is ever given the chance to implement it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait until you hear my speech.

—The honourable member will tell me all about capital gains tax! He believes in a capital gains tax but he has welched on the people who elected him because he promised it to them. The Labor Party talks of helping the small businessman yet it proposes for him high inflation and price fixing. Price fixing is something which I recollect, as young as I might appear to be. Price fixing has only two results: It either sets prices at the highest common denominator or it turns honest men into dishonest men.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Opposition really likes small business, why does it not suggest to this House that we sell Canberra's ACTION buses to the men who drive them and create another 400 or 500 small businessmen? They could operate as subcontractors to the authority which now controls them. No doubt they would supply a very efficient service. They could choose the number of hours they wanted to work and I am sure they would be able to profit by such an arrangement. I suggest that the Opposition would go to the barricades if such a suggestion came from the Government, as good as it might be for the workers concerned. It would give them profit and it would give them the right to decide their own future. But the Opposition believes that everyone should be a wage earner, and preferably a wage earner of the Government. So why does it express concern for small businessmen? Maybe it needs their votes to get elected, but I hope the small businessmen have long memories. Honourable members might talk of bankruptcies and things of that nature but I have been a small businessman for 20-odd years and I know this Government has always made life better for small businessmen, principally because it let us make up our own minds as to how we went broke if that was what we chose to do. As I said, when we made profits we broke our necks to go out and spend them, which in turn almost always created employment.

The Government sees inflation as the principal enemy and its strategy is to keep the money supply in line with the goods and services that Australians can produce and afford. It is interesting that we so often talk of the effects on the world economy of the decision of the member nations of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase dramatically the price of oil and then steadily increase it further. Nevertheless, two or three years ago I heard one of that organisation's senior people admit to the huge burden that they had imposed on their own economies when they increased oil prices. They found that when they exported their oil at this wonderful new price they so affected the economies of other countries that those countries had to increase the prices of the goods that the oil exporting countries wanted to buy back. The total effect was that they were not doing so well. In terms of tonnes of oil, their purchasing power was not much better than it was before. Yet now, when the world has taken the message, which Australia will take on its labour force in due course, and has refused to buy the product any more, they find themselves still paying the overseas price for the goods they wish to import while the price of their own product is going down. It is a warning for all Australians: If we do not produce, we will die.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have witnessed in the Parliament today a speech on the state of the nation by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) which admits that his Government has failed the Australian people. He has attempted to turn what should have been a speech of resignation into a paean of praise by comparing the disastrous economic performances of other European countries with the very poor performance of the Australian economy. In other words, he has compared bad with bad. In recent speeches around the country the Prime Minister has emphasised the theme that Australia is doing well despite a continuing world recession. How hollow these words sound in relation to the Governor-General's Speech of 18 months ago which heralded the forthcoming policies of this Government. We all remember the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: My Government will give particular attention to encouraging the growth of the private sector and to increasing the freedom of choice of taxpayers in spending their own incomes.

After the 18 months since that statement was made, that part of the private sector which employs over half of the Australian work force-namely, small business-could not be in worse shape. An indication of this is the increasing number of bankruptcies, rising from 2,196 to 1976-77 to 5,112 in 1980-81, an increase of 133 per cent in four years. In discussions with me a number of small business proprietors in my electorate of La Trobe have expressed their concern at the lack of spending power of the general public and excessive interest rates , both of which mean that profits are hardly covering overheads. Many small shopkeepers are working for a net return which is far less than average weekly earnings. The Government claims that there have been large increases in real disposable household incomes in the past year but this claim is totally untrue. Increases in taxation, in interest rates and in health insurance premiums have all combined to reduce disposable household incomes.

Another policy statement included the claim that the Government had a commitment 'to assist homeless persons, to assist low or moderate income earners in house purchasing and in the strong commitment . . . to welfare housing'. But, as has been pointed out in this House on a number of occasions, next to unemployment housing is the most serious social problem in Australia. However, Commonwealth funds for public housing have dropped from 3.9 per cent of the total Budget outlays in 1974-75 to one per cent in 1981-82. This represents a reduction in real terms from $1,413m in 1974-75 to $399m this year. This reduction is particularly noticeable in the outer eastern region of Melbourne in which my electorate is situated. The lack of rental housing, both public and private, has reached such an acute stage that many estate agents no longer advertise rental vacancies. The Youth Emergency Accommodation Group of the outer eastern region has provided figures in relation to requests for emergency accommodation for the 10-month period July 1980 to April 1981. In that period, of a total of 672 requests for accommodation from homeless youth in the region, accommodation could be found for only 193 young people. Over 479 young people had to seek accommodation elsewhere.

In such circumstances hundreds of young people are forced to find shelter in railway stations, empty buildings, cars, parks and bus shelters in the hope that they can obtain a night's rest. Caravan parks in the area, which are normally expected to provide temporary accommodation for itinerant workers and holidaymakers, are now full of permanent residents who have no other housing options. It is also important to remember that unemployed young people under 18 years of age still receive only $36 per week but are expected to pay weekly rentals of $50 to $65 for a two-bedroom house in Bayswater or Boronia, in my electorate. In the outer eastern region of Melbourne rents have increased by 20 per cent in the past year. In Victoria as a whole 30,000 families are on the Housing Commission waiting list for homes to rent or buy.

Private housing is in a similar crisis situation as a result of the rise in home loan interest rates from 9.5 per cent in February 1980 to 12.5 per cent now . This increase of 3 per cent has meant an increase in home mortgage repayments of $65 per month, to a total of $327 per month. In addition, many home buyers are paying up to 20 per cent interest on a second mortgage. Members on the Government side of the House point to the fact that few people are selling their houses because of increased mortgage repayments. Whilst I would question the argument that home buyers are not being forced to sell because of threatened foreclosures, it is a fact that selling the family home is the last step to be taken by families experiencing financial difficulties. They will cut their costs on education, health, personal necessities and even food before they will place their home on the market.

An increasing number of people are coming to my electorate office to seek my help in interceding with building societies and other relevant institutions to enable them to meet their mortgage and rental commitments. As for the young would-be home owners, there is no hope for them unless both partners are working in permanent and well-paid jobs. This is the housing situation 18 months after the Government's announced policies, which it stated would assist people who wanted to own their own homes and who needed cheap rental accommodation. As in all other areas of Government policy, Australia has moved backwards, not forwards. The Prime Minister has stated that living standards have been improved . Such a statement would be a joke if it were not so tragic for Australians, the greater majority of whom have suffered from the past 6 1/2 years of Liberal- National Country Party government.
I would like to turn to some of the comments contained in the Prime Minister's statement. He said:
In the area of social welfare the automatic indexation of pensions has given income security to a very significant number of people in the community.

I know that this statement is nonsensical because I have talked to many pensioners over the past year who are desperately searching for some way of keeping up with the cost of living. Even automatic indexation is six months behind rising prices. Why should pensioners have to wait six months for cost of living increases? Time and again in this Parliament I have brought up the matter of threshold levels which are disadvantaging pensioners both in the receipt of fringe benefits and the reduction of pensions as a result of small amounts of additional income. These threshold levels need to be adjusted so that pensioners can receive more income before their pensions are reduced and before they are taxed on the modest incomes they receive. The threshold levels for fringe benefits must also be increased because rising inflation has meant that only pensioners who are well below the poverty line can receive fringe benefits. The only answer the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has given to the calls from the Opposition for a raising of the threshold levels is that it will all depend upon the capacity of the Government to make the adjustments.

The Prime Minister claims that his Government has given income security for pensioners but the pensioners know that that statement is untrue, as any reader of their newspaper, The Australian Pensioner, will surely know. In the context of Government statements one must not forget the recent utterances of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) who said, in effect, that too many rich pensioners are dipping into the public purse and something must be done to stop the process. Of course, his statements have been repudiated by the Prime Minister because of the Lowe by-election. But the statement was approved by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and it does not take any imagination to realise that what has really happened is that the Minister for Industry and Commerce, for his own good reasons, has revealed future Government strategy. The Government will attempt, as usual, to fool the electorate prior to the next election into voting it into government. Only if it can gain government again will it move against the pensioners.
Another statement by the Prime Minister which would be funny if it were not so tragic for the average taxpayer is this comment:
I want to reaffirm that it is the policy of the Government to make further income tax reductions when it is economically responsible to do so.

How many times over the past six and a half years has the Prime Minister made such comments? But instead of reducing taxation he has increased it. Since the Fraser Government came to office revenue from taxes has increased by 24 per cent in real terms. However, the burden of taxation is falling not on those who can most afford to pay but on the wage and salary earner who cannot obtain concessions and subsidies and who cannot avoid taxes as can the rich supporters of this Government. The wage and salary earner has seen taxes bite heavily into pay packets as inflation pushes incomes into higher tax brackets but there has been no relief from the Government. Instead the Government took away the half indexation provisions which would have reduced the effects of inflation and went on to increase sales taxes substantially. It is against this background of tax increases that the Prime Minister has the gall to come into this House and to talk about further income tax reductions.

It was noticeable that the Prime Minister and the Ministers who followed him in this debate had little to say about unemployment. As I mentioned earlier, unemployment and housing are the two most serious social problems in Australia today. Yet the Government has no answers to those major problems. Since 1976 the Government has seen unemployment figures, as published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, grow from 301,600, or 4.9 per cent of the labour force, to 386, 400, or 5.7 per cent of the labour force. The figure is even higher today. As has been pointed out by the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research of the Melbourne University, supported by the Victorian Chamber of Commerce, unemployment is likely to become even worse during 1982.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures are deficient because they do not record the numbers of people who would want to work but know that it is a waste of time to register for employment because of a lack of job opportunities. Reliable estimates by several university departments have established that for every one person registered for work there is one other person who is not registered but who would also like a job. It is only over the past seven years that hidden unemployment has become a problem but it is a phenomenon which should not be ignored. So the total number of people seeking work is probably over 800,000. The worst aspect of unemployment is the demoralisation and apathy which it generates in young people. Our young people represent Australia's investment in the future and this Government has nothing to offer them.

Speaker after speaker on the Government side of the House talked about the present prosperity of Australia. But it is all words. Ask the average taxpayer, the pensioner, the home buyer-the unemployed whether we are prosperous. Ask the three million Australians who are underprivileged whether we are prosperous. Let me remind the House again of the Prime Minister's words:
It is an undoubted fact that as a result of our policies Australia has prospered in recent years while the rest of the world has been stagnating.

There is no doubt that some people have prospered-tax avoiders, overseas investors, and the recipients of capital gains, for example. It is the blatant hypocrisy and deception which the Prime Minister's statement indicates which makes a mockery of this Parliament. If there could be some honesty and sincerity from the Government the Australian people would have a greater regard for politics and the processes of the Parliament. When the Prime Minister makes blatantly dishonest statements such as 'the living standards of Australia's families have been improved' it is inevitable that the debate in the Parliament is described 'as a piece of theatre', as it was by a commentator on the Australian Broadcasting Commission radio program P.M. tonight.

In my maiden speech in the House over a year ago I pointed out that government planning and control could prevent the dislocation of our economy but that Liberal philosophy, which believes in the free flow of market forces unhindered by government regulation, will cause a deterioration in the lives of the Australian people. Unfortunately my words have proved all too true. As I also pointed out at that time, only the policies of the Australian Labor Party can alleviate the effects of the economic crisis which has been developing in this country for the past six and a half years. Our great mineral wealth has insulated us from the worst effects of the recession which has spread from the United States of America. But our mineral wealth has been squandered by this Government and it can no longer insulate us from the insane economic policies of the Reagan Administration. We need a public planning framework within which development plans can be formulated which will benefit all Australian people. We need a restructuring of our taxation system so that wealthy individuals and corporations contribute their fair share to government revenue. We need to revitalise public enterprise so that the public sector can really achieve its objectives of serving the Australian people. Only the Australian Labor Party can provide these initiatives. The Prime Minister's statement can only serve to strengthen the ALP vote in the Lowe by-election and, inasmuch as the statement also reflects the views of the Victorian Liberal State Government, it will help the ALP to win government in that State on 3 April.

TALK.START.PARA: —So much has been said in this House regarding youth unemployment that I feel I should refer to two publications launched on 26 February by the Youth Education Advisory Committee of the Whittlesea Shire. I do so because I believe the Government lacks depth of understanding of the problem. These reports illustrate this. The publications are entitled: 'Youth Employment and Unemployment in an Outer Suburban Area: A Survey of Employers' and 'Youth Employment and Unemployment in an Outer Suburban Area: An Overview'. The study was carried out by the Youth Education Advisory Committee. It was analysed, compiled and published by the Melbourne State College and was funded by a grant from the Northern Region transition Education Advisory Committee. Whilst the report applies to the Shire of Whittlesea I suspect that it would apply also to the other municipalities in my electorate of Scullin, namely, the Shires of Diamond Valley and Bulla and the City of Preston which are areas of high youth unemployment and youth problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I can only quote some of the findings, recommendations and conclusions of the report so that the ordinary decent Australian citizen to whom the Prime Minister so often refers can draw his or her own conclusions. Firstly, there appears to be only a minority of firms which employ no young people. That is scarcely remarkable. There are significantly more young men than young women employed in the region. Yet later the survey shows that there is quite a marked preference and need for young women to have employment close to their home area. There are likely to be few vacancies available for young workers in the next 12 months. The vacancies that are available will be replacement vacancies, not new positions. A large proportion of these vacancies will occur in a few big firms but also a large proportion will occur in the many small firms which might, by virtue of their numbers, be more difficult for employment services to cover.

Further, small firms are more likely to have experienced difficulty in filling positions in the past. A small number of vacancies may be expected among firms that have not previously employed young people. This suggests that youth unemployed groups should consider extending their activities to include firms that previously have not employed young people, and also, may I add, to a concentration on small firms. But then comes the crunch. The main reasons for not employing more young people have more to do with the structural and economic factors than the shortcomings of individual applicants. I think that is significant. It is a reflection on the state of the economy. A strategy for a reduction of unemployment that focuses on training and improvement of young applicants would appear to offer only small scope for alleviating the problems of youth unemployment. Yet this is the very strategy which this Government offers. The Government tells us that it will alleviate this youth unemployment by focusing attention on the training and improvement of young applicants. That is the very thing which the survey of employers indicates is not satisfactory.

I now turn to some of the observations that were made in this survey of employers. Whilst it was found that the Commonwealth Employment Service was well respected by employers, it was felt that the Service did not advertise its services adequately nor did it communicate enough with employers. In the brief time which is available to me it is not possible to deal with this rich source of information and the recommendations. Yet we find the Minister in Victoria, Mr Brian Dixon, advertising in the St Kilda electorate campaigns for the employment of young people. Thousands of dollars of public money have been spent on advertising, which is obviously election advertising. Up to six photographs of the Minister have appeared in the one advertisment. That was paid for by public moneys and by his Ministry. Yet here is an area of high youth unemployment which is receiving no assistance.
