TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members may recall my speech in the adjournment debate on 17 November last year in which I discussed the unsatisfactory position with respect to the establishment of computerised legal information retrieval systems in Australia. Unfortunately, the situation appears not to have greatly advanced from what I then described and indeed in some respects it has got worse. Since my earlier comments both the Victorian and New South Wales governments have issued invitations for proposals to establish computerised legal information retrieval systems in their States. Each invitation envisages the granting of a monopoly licence to an operator to establish and run a system in and for the State concerned. This seems to me a retrogressive step. Quite apart from the uniform principles of the common law, much State legislation is uniform. The laws of this Parliament apply to all States, apply throughout Australia. In these circumstances, naturally, we find a strong body of opinion among members of the legal profession and other likely users that the CLIR systems should have databases which are national in scope and run on an all-States basis for the benefit of the country as a whole and not confined to the interests of a single State.

SPEECH.PARA: A lawyer should be able to research in a simple, efficient way so that by using a single search command on a terminal he would be able to do an across the board search of the whole of this country's current legislation or of the whole of the superior courts' reported case law. Against this background the current proposals of New South Wales and Victoria are not in the public interest. Firstly, the dissemination of legal material in this country will be fragmented between the States. Claims that the various State systems could be compatible are no answer because there is no guarantee that the systems will remain compatible as political and budgetary priorities change. Secondly, the interests of the less populous States-all but the eastern mainland States-will be substantially disadvantaged. Thirdly, the State proposals have all the evils of State sponsored regulated monopolies. Under monopolies no incentive exists for an operator to provide services over and above the minimum stipulated by government. The incentive to provide comprehensive, economical, efficient and friendly services is provided by the spur of competition, not by the dead hand of regulation. Fourthly, as I stated last November, governments have a well known unsatisfactory track record in the provision of comprehensive, up to date and consolidated legal materials.

In a recent letter in the journal of the Law Council of Australia, the writer observed that the copyright argument, favoured by governments and apparently being advanced on behalf of all governments, that a system cannot be set up without the involvement of governments is a specious one. Governments can easily waive any such rights and place statutes and judgments in the public domain where they naturally belong. The Commonwealth Government holds a responsibility to the nation as a whole. The Commonwealth cannot condone the current situation and in particular the grant of State monopoly licences. It should amend the Copyright Act to allow statutes, regulations and cases to be freely disseminated . In the meantime it can fulfil its obligations by allowing those capable private organisations which wish to disseminate legal information through electronic media to do so without unreasonable restriction. That is not the position at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House the implications of an incident which occurred on 25 February at the B. F. Goodrich chemical plant in Altona, Victoria, when leaking vinyl chloride gas caused the evacuation of 500 workers. The gas leak, which took more than six hours to bring under control, caused the threat of a devastating explosion, according to fire brigade officials, and exposed workers at the plant and people in the surrounding community to grave risks of cancer from the highly toxic gas. That the leaking gas did not ignite, as happened in a similar incident in Mexico in 1975, causing the death of 50 people, is an example of monumental good luck. That the gas leak occurred in the first place is a reflection on Victoria's archaic occupational safety regulations-a situation which will be remedied by the Cain Labor government after its election on 3 April. The leak occurred because the storage tank for the vinyl chloride monomer was installed with only one safety valve rather than a double valve system which is a standard safety requirement.

SPEECH.PARA: After evacuating workers from the plant, the company was anxious to play down the real danger from a potential explosion. It stated that there was no danger to the general community from the leak. The lie to the statement was given by the authorities which cleared an area two kilometres either side of the factory- an extremely large area-which suggests that a massive explosion could have occurred in Altona, taking with it petrol storage tanks in the vicinity. A car engine could have ignited the highly flammable gas. All this occurred because the company neglected to install an adequate safety valve system and the Victorian Liberal Government regards the enforcement of adequate safety standards an unnecessary intrusion on private industry.

A second and equally serious aspect of this incident is the toxic effects of exposure to the leaking vinyl chloride on the workers involved. Only in the last decade has research revealed vinyl chloride to be a potent carcinogen causing a well-known liver cancer called hepatanas and angiosaroma, a rare type of the same disease. The extent to which these diseases have already occurred amongst workers in the plastics industry is not known. Nobody knows the full costs to the health of workers in the plastics industry but isolated examples occur. For example, B. F. Goodrich of the United States of America revealed that three PVC workers in its Louisville, Kentucky factory had died of that disease of the liver between 1971 and 1974. Yet Goodrich was one of the major firms in the industry to oppose the introduction of regulations by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration in the United States which would control exposure levels of vinyl chloride monomer to workers in the industry. The United States regulations passed in 1975 allow a permissible exposure level of one part per million.

In Victoria companies are generally allowed to undertake their own monitoring of air quality. We therefore do not know the full extent of exposure caused during this incident but certainly maintenance workers close to the storage plants must have experienced very high exposures. An article in the Age on 27 March reported that later measurements showed a peak level of about 100 parts per million. A scientist from La Trobe University said that a single exposure to VCM could initiate cancer. And yet this company, B. F. Goodrich, is known to regularly release vinyl chloride, and has done so at least 17 times in the last five years according to the Environmental Protection Authority. It is a national scandal that adequate regulations on the effects of hazardous chemicals such as VCM are not available.

At its October conference last year, the Victorian branch of the Australian Labor Party adopted a new and comprehensive policy on occupational health and safety. It will provide a sound legislative program for the incoming government after 3 April. Let us all be clear why the Labor Party will win a victory in Victoria. It is because the Party has spent a great deal of time and effort in developing sound policies in areas such as economic management, transport and so on. The Party's policy states that Victoria's laws on occupational health and safety are an embarrassing disgrace. The ALP policy states:
There is far too much law. Much of it is out-dated and unrelated to modern conditions.

When the Cain Labor Government has had time to sort out the mess created by successive Liberal governments, it will introduce an occupational safety and health Act which will at least provide some government controls. The Act will rationalise the existing chaotic administrative arrangements, provide for and enforce standards related to the causes of work-related injury and disease, give workers and their unions a say in safety policies and establish effective licensing systems for toxic substances and hazardous chemicals. The Victorian Labor Government will act. The national Government ought to act to establish overall standards in relation to environmental and occupational health.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) in lamenting the passing of Professor W. E. H. Stanner who died on 8 October last year at the age of 75. It had been our intention to make our contributions on the same evening but unfortunately that was not possible. Professor Stanner held distinguished appointments at the Australian National University where he was Professor of Anthropology and Sociology from 1964 to 1970. He was made Emeritus Professor and Honorary Fellow of the Australian National University in 1971. He held important appointments with government through his membership of the Council for Aboriginal Affairs and he worked directly with this Parliament through its committee system. In 1968 he delivered the Australian Broadcasting Commission series of Boyer lectures entitled 'After the Dreaming'. I recall the extraordinary effect that those lectures had on me and thousands of other Australians. The lectures were lucidly written and he spoke beautifully when delivering them. Those lectures represented a turning point in contemporary community attitudes as far as Aboriginal Australians are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I first came into contact with Professor Stanner during 1974-75 when he was an adviser to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs , of which I was a member. The Committee was then involved in its work on the conditions of the Aboriginal people at Yirrkala, the housing conditions of Aborigines in New South Wales and the conditions of Aboriginal people in south- west Western Australia. I was immediately struck by Professor Stanner's dignity and his wisdom and the fact that he was incapable of ever being overbearing or self-important. But behind the quiet, gentle and occasionally wry exterior there existed a burning passion for Aboriginal people and their awful circumstances. This had a huge effect on me. Here was a man, twice my age, who had been involved in Aboriginal issues for over 40 years, who had held academic posts and government posts and who was respected widely by black and white Australians, a man who must have been immensely discouraged by the lack of progress during all that time, and by the lack of response to his own extraordinary efforts, his reasoned arguments, his occasional display of heartfelt anguish about what he saw. Yet despite all of this he was still fighting inconspicuously, still undertaking arduous travel to the country where Aboriginal people still lived, putting up with and persevering with ignorant white attitudes, still ploughing on and never giving up. His attitude and his example provided me with a focus and a framework with which to approach this great issue.

His knowledge was immense, though modestly and carefully imparted, and was of enormous benefit to me and those of my colleagues who cared to listen. Although there must have been many disappointments for him, I am quite sure that he had a central impact on what is now a widely held respect for Aboriginal history and culture evidenced throughout Australia. He helped Australians to face up quite squarely to the feeling of collective guilt which we should all experience when we think of the disgrace of the last 200 years. This is a necessary cleansing process which we all must endure in order to plan a decent future of co- operation between all Australians. His part in this national awakening was probably best explained by his friend and colleague, Dr H. C. Coombs when he was writing in the ANU Reporter, when he said:

There are few more influential words in the formation of contemporary attitudes than those which Bill embodied in his Boyer Lectures After the Dreaming. If at long last greater justice is achieved for Aboriginal Australians it will be due, in no small measure, to the changes in human understanding and compassion which those words have set in train.

He was a founding member of the Aboriginal Treaty Committee and the greatest monument which we could provide in memory to Professor Stanner would be to persevere with and conclude that treaty which would secure a future for all Aboriginal Australians. Aboriginal Australians have lost a great friend and champion and we have all lost a very gifted scholar, a generous and compassionate humanitarian, and a truly remarkable Australian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently I received an invitation to attend and address a rally to support local child care services. Several child care centres were involved in the rally such as the centre at St John's Avenue, Springvale; the centre at Noble Street in Noble Park; the Family Day Care program; the Keysborough Freedom Club, and so on. The invitation said:

SPEECH.PARA: If you value child care services, pack a picnic lunch and bring your family to Burden Park as a demonstration of support for the continuation of federally funded child care services in Springvale.

And indeed, this was a demonstration with a difference. There were no marchers and no police. Concerned mums and dads turned up with their children, sitting on picnic chairs and blankets, eating their picnic lunches and listening to the Mayor of Springvale and other speakers. Many of those present have worked for years to improve the quality of child care services. They expressed their opposition to the Government's intention to subsidise commercial child care centres.

In view of clear evidence that high quality care and education during pre- school years is of critical importance to the development of each individual, one can ask: What is the Fraser Government's real intention in this field? If one looks at the last Budget of this Government it is obvious that it did not intend to maintain or to improve the services for children and their families. The amount allocated for child care programs in the 1981-82 Budget was the same as the previous year. This in fact means a reduction of approximately 15 per cent in real terms because of high inflation caused by this Government's own policies. In its true style, to dupe the electorate, the Government found some money for the funding of the child care program before the 1980 elections. It also invited further applications for child care funding, only to reject most of over 400 applications. Yet it finds hundreds of thousands of dollars for the Minister to pump into private child care centres. When it comes to boosting private profits, the Fraser Government always finds the money. It pickpockets the taxpayer, the ordinary Australian family man, to finance the opulent. Since Fraser grabbed power in 1975--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will refer to the Prime Minister as such.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. Since the Prime Minister grabbed power in 1975, there has been a gradual but consistent redistribution of wealth directed by the Prime Minister from the poor to the wealthy, a reallocation of resources from the public sector to private profits.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not one who will denigrate the private sector in child care. I acknowledge that private child care facilities fill an enormous gap, even though most of those involved in the profession of providing the services question the profit motivation of private child care and consider that there is a clear conflict of interest between the provision of a good service with trained staff and profit making. I, for one, know people who, side by side with profitability, have a human interest in providing a good service. I can assure the many parents who are forced to use private facilities because there are not enough community child care centres that, in most cases, their children are in good hands. However, I urge them to take more interest in the management of these centres and to insist on the employment of fully qualified staff.

Whilst I am not opposed to private child care centres, my first responsibility is to the public, to community child care. After all, we are dealing with public funds, and therefore we have to provide for the public sector. The Fraser Government, of course, has a different philosophy. It milks the people and subsidises its rich friends and the services for them. It takes away funds from State schools and gives them to rich private schools so that children of the rich can frolic in expensive swimming pools built by wealthy schools on public money, while the children of workers are crammed like sardines into portable classrooms.

The Fraser Government is fond of the expression 'user pays'. So it wants to raise the fees in community child care centres to price the ordinary families out of child care facilities, while at the same time children of wealthy parents attending pre-school sections of prestige private schools have their fees subsidised through the Schools Commission. This Government wants to turn the clock back. It wants us to return to charity kindergartens for the poor and disadvantaged, with no service for the rest of the community whatsoever. We on this side of the House believe that our greatest assets are our children, the future citizens of Australia, and we pledge ourselves to look after them. We will first restore our spending on child care to the 1975 level and increase it gradually as soon as we get rid of this reactionary government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise a matter which was referred to briefly by the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins). It concerns a practice which is very widespread and one which is out of character with the general philosophy which is being expressed by this Government and by other governments. We will all be aware that an election campaign is taking place in Victoria. Certainly we are all aware that a by-election is taking place in New South Wales. I think that the tenor of a number of activities in this Parliament indicates that. What I want to draw to the attention of the House and the nation is the manner in which duplicity is occuring in respect of the funding of elections in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: A little over a year ago it was decided in New South Wales that public funding of election campaigns would become the policy of that State. The conservative parties made noises which indicated that the use of public funds for election campaigning was an improper practice. I think we should examine what is going on in Victoria. The honourable member for Scullin drew attention to the fact that youth employment schemes for areas of Victoria in which there are high levels of unemployment were not able to obtain funding. In some instances these schemes, which are of assistance even though they do not provide a great many jobs, have not been funded because the Department has claimed that it lacked funds. Over the last six months in Victoria there has been in local or limited distribution newspapers a long series of advertisments carrying multiple photographs of the particular Minister, Mr Brian Dixon, which newspapers are distributed mainly throughout his electorate.

There are many-I repeat, many-local newspapers which circulate through electorates in which there is high unemployment and the need for information. But, of course, the advertisments are not aimed at informing the community of the Government's policies. There was a time when communities knew what governments were doing because they were doing something, and the community understood what they were about. But when we have a government which governs through an office of a public relations firm, which invests more public money in public relations than it does in actually doing things, we have a situation in which public funds are being diverted to purposes for which it is not proper that they be expended.

It may be arguable whether public funding of election campaigns should take place, but at least where the offer is made to all sections of the community that are genuinely contesting an election, it is known that that money is being made available for election purposes. But in the State of Victoria, the State Electricity Commission, the conservation ministry and other ministries are preparing and presenting material in highly professional, costly television advertising campaigns which have been designed to dovetail into the Liberal party's election campaign exactly. The moralists, the people who claim that they represent the public interest, who claim that taxpayers' money should not be spent in supporting election campaigning by political parties, are spending more money on advertising themselves, the Ministers of their Governments, as Ministers, than is being spent on the support programs which they are supposed to be advertising. In one case a department prepared a massive advertising campaign which was $10m over committed before the scheme was even advertised in the newspapers. It is a means by which a government can put forward its election propaganda at taxpayers' expense, a means by which a government which would throw up it arms in horror at a suggestion of public funding is misappropriating the funds of the State of Victoria to purposesd for which they were never collected and never allocated, and they should not be used for these purposes.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

(2) Is it a fact that 57 per cent of all new grants in 1981 are for one year only; if so, what are the reasons for this practice.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: High Court Decision on Suppliers of Information

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981 (Hansard, page 3000) the honourable member for Fadden asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the recent case in the High Court of Australia known as Shaddock v. City of Parramatta in which the Court has ruled that many individuals and companies providing information to others as part of a service will be liable for any negligence in providing the information if another has suffered loss by relying on it. Has the Minister considered the application of this decision to members of parliament and their staffs who are continually called upon by constituents for advice of a sometimes delicate nature which, if relied upon and incorrect, could cause a loss.

At the time I provided the honourable member with a precis of the decision to which he referred and undertook to refer to the Attorney-General for further advice on the application of the decision to members.
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

Before the Shaddock decision the Privy Council had held in Mutual Life and Citizens' Assurance Co. Ltd v. Evatt (1970) 122 C.L.R. 628, that a duty of care in respect of the making of statements of fact or opinion is cast only on a person who carries on a business or profession which involves the giving of advice of a kind calling for special skill and competence, or on persons who, while not carrying on such a business or profession, nevertheless profess to have a comparable competence. The essence of the judgments in Shaddock is that the duty of care is not so narrowly confined but will arise whenever a person gives information or advice to another upon a serious matter in circumstances where the former realises, or ought to realise, that he is being trusted to give the best of his information or advice as a basis for action on the part of the other party and where it is reasonable, in all the circumstances, for the other party to act on that information or advice.

I am not aware of any reason why the duty of care in those circumstances, as expounded by the High Court, should not be found to be cast upon members of Parliament to the same extent as it is cast upon other members of the community . I note that liability for damages may be avoided by issuing, at the time of giving the information or advice, an adequate disclaimer of liability for any loss or damage that may arise as a result of acting upon the information or advice. Should the honourable member require advice on appropriate terms for a disclaimer of liability or on the application of the decision in particular circumstances, he should consult his own legal advisers.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Pet Meat Controls in Licensed Abattoirs

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Humphreys Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are licensed abattoirs required to keep a tally of the number of processed kangaroos they handle for use as pet meat.
(2) Are there any checks carried out by Commonwealth Health Inspectors on abattoirs processing kangaroos for pet foods.
(3) Are Commonwealth inspectors employed to inspect processing of kangaroo meat .
(4) Are abattoirs required to be licensed to process kangaroo meat; if so, how many licensed abattoirs exist in Australia.
(5) How many kangaroos have they handled in each year since 1975.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Kangaroos may only be processed for pet food at depots or knackeries licensed by State authorities. Such establishments are required by State authorities to keep records of numbers of kangaroos processed.
(2) There are not checks by Commonwealth inspectors on premises processing kangaroos for pet food.
(3) Commonwealth inspectors are employed to inspect kangaroo meat prepared in registered game establishments for export for human consumption.
(4) Game establishments must be registered by the Department of Primary Industry under the Exports (Meat) Regulations. There are four such establishments.
(5) These four establishments handled no kangaroos in the period 1975-1979, and in the years 1980, 1981 and 1982 to date, handled 53,394, 191,041 and 6,013 kangaroos respectively.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLeay Mr L.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he say whether under section 212 (a) (4) of the United States Immigration and Nationalities Act, U.S. immigration officials are obliged to exclude sexual deviants from entry to the United States.

(2) Can he also say whether the expression 'sexual deviant' has been interpreted to include homosexuals; if so, will the Australian Government raise this denial of the rights of sexual choice of Australian citizens with the United Nations Commission on Human Rights.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Section 212 (a) (4) of the United States Immigration and Nationalities Act includes sexual deviants as a class of aliens ineligible to receive visas and excluded from admission into the United States.

(2) Regulations issued pursuant to the Act define sexual deviance as including homosexuality. I understand that, in implementing these provisions, United States' policy is that officials should not initiate any inquiries to discover whether an applicant for a visa is a homosexual. The Australian Government does not intend to raise the application of Section 212 (a) (4) of the United States Act with the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. The Australian Government has however traditionally supported constructive initiatives aimed at protecting the rights of social minorities.
